The eldelt Miss entreated me very much to play, but I refused, and said I could not: I did not chuse it. As soon as they had got to play, I retired to the next room; Mrs. Griffinburg came unto me, and told me she wanted me to see the apartment she had been preparing for me, for that I could not have that room I was in in the morning; theresore she carri∣ed me up into a stone garret: it seemed to be all stone; it was very cold, and struck like a well, and was among all the fervants, that I was very much frightened and uneafy about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Was there a window?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P:
There was a window cut out of the lead∣ing; I could see nothing but a bit of the leading of the
house, which looked out upon the gutter, and a bit of a sky light. I was very much frightened and uneasy, and thought it very odd I could not have a better room in such a house as that. I was afraid that now he had done with me himself, that he did intend I should be ex∣posed to any body that he might send. Upon that I told Mrs. Griffinburg that I durst not lie there; she, upon that, said, to oblige me, she would bring up a little bed, and He there a night or two. Then I came down stairs again to supper.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: With whom did you sup?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: With the lady that came to see him, Doc∣tor Griffinburg, Madam Saunier, and the governess, the two Misses, and Lord Baltimore; but I neither eat nor drank. On Sunday I kept up in the garret, and they came often and disturbed me, that I could have no rest any where. I came down stairs to breakfast, and then went up again, and came down again to dinner; and after dinner I stood up at the window, and as I was sstanding up at the window, (this was the corner win∣dow, and looked toward Hampstead) as I was standing, I thought I saw Mr. Davis. the person to whom I was en∣gaged.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Who was in the room with you?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P:
Two more ladies that came to dinner that day, Madam Saunier, and the governess and the two children, and myself; they six were standing up at the fire side while I went to the window; there I saw Mr. Davis; and when I first saw him I was so struck I could not tell how to stand; and fearing that he should not see me, when he looked up I thought he did not know me; but he went behind a wall towards the Foundling Hospital, and there peeped two or three times, till I was sure he knew me. He took a book out of his pocket, and made a motion with his hand for me to write; with that I waved my hand for him to come further, but he did not understand me; therefore, when I went to the next window, at first sight I lost him, but seeing him again, I waved my hand for him to come further, and then I ran into the next room, which was the room Lord Baltimore generally sat in; but I ran in hap hazard, without thinking whether he was there or no, and called out to him in great agony, I cannot come to you! I cannot come to you! This was the other corner room, the west side of the house; I crossed the room the bow-window is in, to go to that
room. He said are you well? But I prevented him, by asking, is my father well! He said Yes, he is well, and we are all well; he said then, how do you do? Then he said, where is Mrs. Harvey? I said I knew nothing of her. He then said, is all well? With that I was ready to drop: I said, good bye, and shut down the window.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: What was the reason of that?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P:
I feared some of the women would come; and before I could get out of the room Lord Baltimore came in. I was so flurried and was all in a tremble, that I did not speak to him as he came in, nor he to me. After this I intreated the maid to get me a pen, ink, and paper, and bring it up into my room, meaning the garret, and not tell any body of it, because I wanted it to amuse me. I lay in the garret that night, and next morning she brought me a pen and ink. I began to write imme∣diately to my father, but was so prevented that I could not go on with my letter: this is a part of it (produced) I did not throw it out of the window: This was on Monday morning. While I was writing this letter, Mrs. Griffinburg came, and said the milliner had brought me some caps; I said I did not care to come down: I told Mrs. Griffinburg she might take what she pleased; she said, I must go down: With that, I went to the milli∣ner; she had brought some caps and cloaks: With that, I took one that I thought looked the decentest, and that was all; Mrs. Griffinburgh intreated me very much to speak for more things: and said I must have some a∣prons. I asked the woman if she had any flowered mus∣lin; she said, she would bring it when she came again; that was the substance of what passed then. I went and I had my breakfast with the family; Then I went up into my garret again, and Mrs. Griffinburg came after me. I asked where my Lord was? she asked if I want∣ed him? I told her, yes. I wanted to know if ever he in∣tended I should see my friends again; for I could not bear to live so. She desired I would take my work and go down stairs; which accordingly I did: And soon af∣ter I came in, Lord Baltimore came in, and clapt me upon the shoulder, as I sat with my back to the door; and told me he was coming to tell me something that would please me very much, that I should see my father that day without fail: With this, to be sure I was pleas∣ed, and went up stairs with intent to put my things on. Mrs. Griffinburgh followed me, and said my father, was sent for to come to her house, and that I must make
haste, and go directly; for he would be there before I could get there; she helped to put on my things; and I came down stairs into the room next the Foundling Hospital; there was a lady that had been there the day before. Lord Baltimore began to tell her what a religious lady I was; and that he was sorry for many things he had said to me. What his reason was for this I don't know, except he thought I should expose him too much. Some time after this, he led me into another room; and when he got me there, he said I now was going to see my father; that he was sent for, and I was going to Mrs. Griffinburg's to meet him. He told me I must say I was willing to stay; and if I would tell my father I was satisfied and easy, he would do any thing for me that I desired: I him that I would, but I must see my father alone: He said, then he would speak to him first. I told him, he might, but I would speak to him alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Explain your meaning.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P:
My meaning was this, Sir, that I might put him into some way of geting me away, if I could not get away with him; then he said, I should take the little Miss, and I should say to my father, I was a companion of that lady; to that I only said, very well: Then we were sent on to Mrs. Griffinburg's house, with an intent to meet my father, in Dean street, Soho; I went to this house; when I was there, I said to Mrs. Griffinburg, I thought you said my father would be here, before I should get here; but I see you have deceived me, as you have done all along. She said he would come presently. In about two hours after this, or rather more, Lord Baltimore and Dr. Griffinburg came. As soon as he came in, I said, I thought you told me I was to see my father; but I see you have deceived me, as you have all along; and I see I shall not see my sather to-night; he said, yes, you shall: But what do you think has happened? Your father has taken up Mrs. Harvey, and put her into the round-house: This gave me some pleasure, but I dared not shew it; I did not know what to answer; at last, I said, I did not suppose that would do any good, for she would not tell where I was: Soon after this, in came another man, and said, Lord Baltimore's house was beset with Justice Fielding's men: He fell into a passion, and said my father must be a fine man indeed, to set to work such rogues as Justice Fielding, and his men, were, that they were the greatest
rognes that could be. I was frightened, and thought my life and my friends were in danger, because he was in such a rage; and I was afraid, having much about the same opinion of him, that he had of Justice Field∣ing, that may-be he might send some of his men and set the homse on fire, or do some mischief. After this there was a great demur about Mrs. Harvey's being at the round-house, and how they should get at her, and get her bailed: Sometime after this, I found that Mrs. Griffinburg had been to set if she could come at her; Mrs. Griffinburg said so, that she could not; with that they were in a great taking, in what to proceed to get this woman bailed.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Who was?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Lord Baltimore, and Dr. and Mrs. Griffinburg; then I studied what I should say and do: At last, I said, that if they had got Mrs. Harvey (I spoke to Lord Baltimore) they might depend upon it, they would never deliever her up, till I was set at liberty: I told them, if they had a mind Mrs. Harvey should be set free, it must be me that could do it; and if they would let me see my father, and I could settle things to my mind, I could release her if I pleased. In two or three hours they got a man to go, upon account of speaking English: they said, if Dr. Griffinburg went, they supposed that the old man (meaning my father) would think he should be run away with: Then they got some tradesman to go along with them to carry the letter, which I had then wrote, if I remember right, at Dr. Griffinburg's, to my father.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: What was the purport of that letter?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: The intent of it was for my father to come to me: We went then to Whitechapel; I went in a coach with Lord Baltimore, Dr. Griffinburg, this man, the Doctor's niece, and the little girl: This was on Monday.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Was there any servants attending the coach?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P:
I saw one run on the side of the coach as I went; it was Pierini, they call him the valet de cham∣bre: We ment to a tavern; I cannot say what it was; I believe I should know it again, if I saw it: There was only a little boy that led the way up to a back room: When we came there, this man, the tradefinan, was sent with the letter to my father: He came back and brought word, that my father had been out ever since nine in the morning, in search of me, and brought the
letter back. I was very loth to go back again; I did not know what to do. I wrote to the landlord of our house, to tell my father to be as easy as he could; for I would send for him next morning at ten, as Lord Bal∣timore told me I should: At that time at the tavern he told me I should send for him in the morning: It was the land-lord of my father's house, whose name is Berry. The tradelman brought word back again, my father was not come home as yet; so Lord Baltimore would go back again, and said, he supposed they were making a fine piece of work at the other end of the town. We went back; and when we came to Covent-Garden, the coach stopped, and the tradesman got out, and went to Justice Fielding's, according to their orders.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Did he come back again?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: He did, along with Justice Fielding's clerk, who brought a card, with his compliments, and that I should see my friends there: I did not know what to say to the man; I made no answer, but gave the card into Lord Baltimore's hand; he read it, and said I should not go. With that, I told the man to tell my friends, that I was there (I mean at Dr. Griffinburg's house) and that I desired my friends to come to me there directly; the man did not come any more; but there was messenger after messenger, came to tell him of men being about the house, and a great mob in the yard; and withal, that there was some women had been crying there. With that, I was afraid it should come out, that I had seen Mr. Davis at the window. I beg∣ged of my Lord, to let me speak to the man first. I found there was another messenger come about some∣thing; I went out of the room, and there was Broughton, which we call the Steward: I asked him what the woman said? He said I was seen out of the window; I told him I was, and I wanted to speak to him about that. I told him I thought that my life depended on its being known; and therefore begged, if he had any value for a person's life, he would not mention to my Lord, that I was seen at the window. He said he would promise no such think, his bread depended upon . I told him he need not fear his bread, he might get it another way. At last, he promised me, that he would not tell him unless he asked him. Then I came into the room, and what passed, I do not know.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: What was the reason of this application to conceal it from my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P:
I thought may-be he would murder me that night, or send me away. After this there was a great deal of consusion, and they talked in another language; I was fearful they were contriving to go some other way, or send me abroad. My Lord was so frightened, he was afraid to go home for fear they should take me out of the coach: I told him they could not take me out unless I would, and that I would not go with Justice Fielding's men. After some time, we set out to go to Lord Baltimore's again. When we came within two or three doors, the coach stopped, by whose order I do not know; Right against the coach there were several men standing; I got up to see if I could see any of my friends; but Lord Baltimore pul∣led me down, asked me what I got up for, and ordered the coach to drive on immediately: which they did as fast as they could; and the men strove to'get into the yard along with the coach; Justice Fielding's men, I believe they were; they strove to get into the gates, and get∣ting out of the coach, I cried out, let the men come in: He pulled me in, and said I should not stay. With that, we went up stairs; when we got there, the little Jew came up, and said, my Lord, Piereni wants you: With that, I got up, and walked about the room in great distress, fearing it was coming out that I had been seen out of the window. I thought I would strive to hide it; I plucked up all the courage I could, and asked him as soon as he came in, what Piereni wanted. He said I had spoke to somebody out of the window; I told him I had; he asked what I had said: I told him; but did not tell my distress because I was afraid: When I had told him, he said he could not blame me, he should have done the same himself. He supposed I was glad to speak to the first I had seen. With this, I was rejoiced, I had been in such a terror before, lest he thould kill me for it. After this, he and the doctor talked a good while in some other language; what, I don't know. By and by, Lord Baltimore said I must go to bed to him; that I must lie with him that night, or he should be wretched: I ; he promised me be would not meddle with me; I thought if I did not, he would make me go to bed to him, so I did go to bed to him, and he did not meddle with me. On Tuesday morning he got up first, and went away, and sent Mrs. Griffinburg to take me up. She came, and said Lord Baltimore wanted me directly: With that, I got up and went to him. When
I came to him, he said, Well, now we will write to your father, and send for him as proposed. I had heard over night, that one Mr. Watts was to come in the morning at ten o'clock: So I said I thought it was bet∣ter to stay till ten o'clock, before I sent to my father. I thought it would be Mr. Davis would come by the name of Watts. At ten o'clock I wrote a letter to my father, the purport of which, if I remember right, was this, that I begged my friends would come with all the decency and respect becoming a nobleman's house: He took the letter, and shewed it Mr. Brown, the attorney, and seemed very much pleased with it, and sent it away. After this, he wanted to know what I should say to my father, and whether I would say as I had told him, that I was willing to stay. I said I would, but I would see my father alone by myself. With that, he said, he would do any thing to make me easy. With that, I said very well, but could not tell what to answer him. He said I should have a house to live in, and live with my friends, if I liked it better than living with him. Just upon that, Piereni came in, and said, my Lord, here is Mr. Watts come; but before that, I should have told you, my Lord said, that whoever came, I must say I was willing to stay. The man came up, and said, there was Mr. Watts. Lord Baltimore went out to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Who was left with you?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I don't know; there was Mrs. Griffin∣burg and Dr. Griffinburg, backwards and forwards; but whether they were in the room or no, I can't say. My Lord brought Mr. Watts up stairs; he was in the first room, and I was in the farthest room; he was brought up stairs; The doors happened to stand a jar, that I could just see them, but I could not hear them. It I remem∣ber right, there was Piereni in the middle room. My Lord talked with Mr. Watts for about ten minutes; and then my Lord came first, and Mr. Watts almost behind him; and my Lord said, Miss, here is a friend of your's; I said, I don't know the gentleman: He then said, Miss, you don't know me, nor do I know you; but I am come from your friends, to know if you are here by your own consent? I answered, yes; but I want to see my father.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: In that very form of words?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P:
I think it was; I was in such a flurry at that time, I can't be positive. He said, very well, Miss, if you are here with your own consent, no body has a right
to take you away; your servant, Madam; and then he talked with Lord Baltimore again.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: What happened to you after this?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I went into the next room; I did not know what to think of Mr. Watts, and I had no thoughts at that time of a lawyer; therefore I went into the middle of the room, to see if I could see any friends about; when I saw none, I opened the window; this was on the first floor: I saw several friends at that time, but one pretty near that I knew, Mr. Cay: He asked me, if I was there by my own consent? I said yes; but I said I wanted to see my father. He said, my father would never come within those walls; I then turned away in a great trembling, and said, then I never shall see him; that was my way of thinking at that time; I thought, that as they would not let him come in, I should never get out. After that, Lord Paltimore came in again, and said, I must go to Lord Mansfield's, and said, I must say I was there with my own consent, and not to tell Lord Mansfield particulars.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Let me ask you this question: Did you before this time, know Lord Mansfield?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I never, as I know of, heard his name.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Don't you take in the news-papers?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, Sir, I did not think of his being a magistrate.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Did Lord Baltimore explain to you, who he was, or why you was to go to him?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Lord Baltimore said, if I did not stand by him now, he should be undone: He then said, will you be faithful to me now, and keep your word; other∣wise I am undone? I said I would? but I would tell my Lord Mansfield, that I wanted to see my father a∣lone. He said, if I would be easy, and tell him I was easy and satisfied, I should have a house, and live with my friends, and have the young man. With that, I told him I would say, I was willing to be there, as I promised him before, but would see my friends alone. He asked, if I would tell my friends the particulars? I told him, yes; I would tell my friends all the truth. After this, he said very little. Another message came for him. He came up, and said, we were to go to Lord Mansfield's immediately. I said, very well, I was very willing. Mr. Brown, the lawyer, my Lord, and myself, went together in Mr. Brown's chariot.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Did you know the business you was going there upon?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I did not.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Now tell all that passed?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: As soon as I came into Lord Mansfield's doors, my Lord Baltimore had hold of my hand up the steps; I clapt my hand upon Mr. Potts, one of the gen∣tlemen that stood in the hall, whom I knew; and he took no notice of me; which struct me very much; because Lord Baltimore had told me, that my friends would not look upon me; and seeing such a repulse from Mr. Potts it struck me very much; I saw several other of my friends there; but I did not speak to any body, nor any body to me; I went into another room, and Lord Mansfield met me at the door? Lord Mansfield asked me to come in; and Lord Baltimore was to stay in the next room; then Lord Mansfield and I were alone, only another gentlemen present. I was not then apprised who Lord Mansfield was.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Tell, distinctly, what passed between you and Lord Mansfield.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: The first words that I remember, were these: Child, was you carried there against your will?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I said, yes, my Lord. He then asked me, if I was kept there against my will; I said, quite against my will; my Lord then said, quite against your will; I said again, quite against my will. He was going to ask me something; but what the words were, I don't know; I said, my Lord, I don't care to go into particulars.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Why did you not tell my Lord Mansfield at that time?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: It was because I did not know, that he had power to release me; if I had known, I should cer∣tainly have told him what had happened. He then said, Miss, I think you are of age? I said, yes: He said, well, Child, are you willing to stay with this man? I said, my Lord, as things are as they are, I am willing, but not without seeing my friends alone: He asked me, what friends? I said my father and my sisters. He desired them to be called. Then he ordered the man would bring Lord Baltimore through such a place, and take me out at the other door, that I might not see my Lord, and there I met my friends alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Did Lord Mansfield stay in the room?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Who were those friends?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: My father and the next sister to me. Soon after that, my other sister came; there was no other person that I remember, when I was with my friends, I asked them, if Lord Mansfield had a power to set me at liberty? They assured me, he had; I asked it again? They said, yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Did the questions come from you to them, or they put the questions to you?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I can't take upon me to say how that was.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: What did you say?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I said, I was heartily willing to go home with them, and desired Lord Mansfield might be called directly, that I might tell him I would go home. Lord Mansfield came to the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Who was in the room?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: My father, and two sisters; he said, child are you willing to go home with Lord Balimore, or your father? I said with my father, my Lord, if it is in your power to let me go; he said, child it is in my power to let you go; but how comes this change of mind? I said, my Lord, because till I saw them, I did not know you had power to release me; he then said child, it is in my power to let you go, let your friends be called, that they may hear your declaration.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Do you know whether Lord Mansfield ex∣plained to you at first his power to release you?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: He might do it, but I do not remember he did. My friends were called in, and will give you an account of what was said: I was so overjoyed when I found myself set at full liberty, that I did not then tell my father or sister what had happened.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: I believe you went away?

SP.SPEAKER: S Woodcock
SP.P: Yes, that I did very joyfully.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Before you went away, did you acquaint your father and sister what had happened to you.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Then you went to Sir John Fieldings?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: At whose desire?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: My friends carried me there, I do not know the reason of my going there.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: What passed between you and Sir John?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Sir John asked me what had passed, I told him in a sew words.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: You was in a room by yourself with him?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, not quite, there were some with me, one or two, but I do not know who.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Was he the first person to whom you related it?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: He was.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: After Sir John heard the story, what passed then?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Sir John asked me, if I was not full of in∣dignation at such usage, and asked me if I was willing to prosecute Lord Baltimore. I answered, yes, if it could be done with safety.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: What did you mean by this?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I meant, that as he was a man of so much money and power, that there might be a great deal of bribery, and that justice might not be done.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: I believe there was an information taken from your own mouth?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Did it contain the whole of the story?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, only answers to such questions as Justice Fielding asked me. From thence I went to a friend's house; I have not been at my father's since for fear, and am afraid to go in the street.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: It seems to me, as if you might have had some chance of escaping from the tavern in Whitechapel?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I had no chance of making my escape, for Lord Baltimore, Dr. Griffinburg, his neice, and the little girl were in the room all the time, and Lord Bal∣timore led me by the arm in and out; there was a man I met in the entry, I had a great mind to speak to, but seeing Lord Baltimore had got four or five of his servants with him, I dared not say any thing to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Had he got so many?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I saw four or five, there was Piereni, and I think I saw two or three in livery.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You say, you have not been at home, since the affair happened?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I have been with several of my friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: With what friends?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P:
The first I went to was Mr. Cay, I staid with him one night: from there I went to Mr. Ridge∣way's, I staid there from Tuesday night to Friday; from there I went to Mr. Wilson's, staid there from Friday to
Sunday; on Sunday I went to Mr. Wallis's, and staid there till the Monday sen'night.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You have been very much hurried and fatigued in shifting about?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: From there I went to Mr. Yeoman's at Westminster, I staid there from that Monday to the Mon∣day three weeks? and from thence I went to Mr. Rutt's in Friday street, and stayed there from Monday to the Friday e'nnight; from Mr. Rutt's, I went to Mr. Keene's, and staid from that time till the fourth week after my going, and from thence I went to Mr. Wallis's; I went to no other persons till I came to Kingston.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: What, not to Mr. Potts's?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Are all or either of these gentlemen concerned in carrying on this prosecution, you are not able to do it?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: A set of gentlemen have lent my father money, upon a note of hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: I understand from your evidence, that you was brought to my house without knowing where you was coming to; that you was, during the whole time you was there, under absolute confinement; that you would have get away if any opportunity had offered and if any opportunity of complaining had offered, you would have done it; do you insist upon this as the truth?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: I think I understand you, that for the first four days, you neither eat nor drank any thing?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, the first two days, to my knowledge, I don't know that I eat any thing, from Wednesday till Saturday morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: And then you only had a dish of tea?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, Sir,

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: I did not understand from your evi∣dence, that you had eat any thing till Sunday dinner?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: The toast and wine I had on Saturday night.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you take any thing solid?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I don't remember that I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You must be very much exhausted, and yet on Sunday you had a long discourse with me, to prove that there was a God, a heaven, a hell, and subjects of that kind; how old are you?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I am twenty-seven.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Will you swear you are no older.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I will swear I am twenty-eight.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Will you swear you are no older?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I will swear I am that.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Will you swear you are no older?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I do not know I need tell; I am twenty∣nine, and that is my age; I cannot exactly tell.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: To the best of your belief, how old are you?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I believe I am thirty next July, I cannot be sure of that, whether I am or no.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: How often had you seen me, before you was brought to my house.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Only three times.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You have told us I expressed some res∣pect and attachment to you; had I never taken the op∣portunity to give you a civil salute, when you was be∣hind the counter!

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, you never did.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You talked of my having said, I would bring a lady to you?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I understood you, that you would bring a lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Might I not have said, I would send?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, I understood that you would bring.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You have told us, you never saw Har∣vey, but twice before this time?

SP.SPEAKER: S Woodcock
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you ever see Isaacs before?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Isaacs, I never saw before.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You had no suspicion where you was going?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Then you trusted yourself with this woman, you had never seen but twice before. You have given an account of drinking tea, the amusement at te∣totum, the seeing the house, and supper, that there was some rudeness offered that night, and that you resented it?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was that repeated the next day?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I don't remember.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did any thing happen the next day, either to make you more alarmed, or make you easier. Was any rudeness offered the second night?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Nothing indecent as I can remember, but violent threats of doing for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P:
I think you said something of Mr.
Smith's drawing your picture; that Mr. Smith was there the third day, drawing your picture?

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: That was a man that was called Richard Smith; Lord Baltimore took that name, and then he said he was not Richard Smith, but it was somebody else.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was it upon the second or the third day?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I think the second day; I reckoned it the second day, because I did not reckon Wednesday one; it was on Friday.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you take any refreshment that day?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Not that I know of.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You say, you was even crying at the time your picture was taking; that you neither drank tea, nor supped; in what room did the rest of the com∣pany drink tea and sup?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: In the room with the bow-window, that looks into Southampton-row.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: That bow-window commands a view of seven or eight foot paths, that branch off; does it not? Do you recollect that Mr. Smith was of the party that drank tea and supped that day?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I believe he was.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Pray will you tell me when you first heard that I had sent any thing to your father?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: On Friday.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Who did you hear it from first?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Lord Baltimore; when I was pleading, that if he had no compassion for me, he might have for my father.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did it come from me?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I believe it did.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did not Dr. Griffinburgh tell you first of all, that I had sent a sum of money to your father?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I don't remember that he did.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did not you express great satisfaction upon hearing I had sent such a sum of money to your father?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, I did not.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: If I understood you, you did not lie down till Friday night; and that you did not pull off your cloaths while in the house.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes, I did on Sunday night; but I never had my cloaths off before.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P:
You have given an account of your
going to Woodcote; had you any notion, when you go into the coach, that you was going to Woodcote?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Had no-body told you?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You was given to understand by me, that you was to to take an airing, and come back, and then see your father.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: In your first information, as read in the King's-Bench, you said you was carried into the coach by force, and they told you, you was going to Woodcote. You have described your sitting in the coach between me and Mrs. Harvey; Did you sit forward or backward?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: My face was to the horses.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You said, Mrs. Harvey was ordered by me to sit forward, so as to shut up the window as well as possible.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: So that you could not so well see the people as they passed by.—You said that, when the coach stopt, you wished it might overturn.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: My reason was, I hoped that, by that means I might have made my escape, if any opportunity had happened. The coach did not stop at all, as I know of.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was the glasses down, or up?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: They were up, till we got off the stones; and then Lord Baltimore put one of them down a little.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: I suppose, as soon as you found that, instead of being carried out for an airing, you was car∣ried further; you was ill disposed to partake of the mirth that went forward in the coach.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I was.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: I understand, you did not know you was going to Woodcote, till you came to Epsom: there are a great many steps, are there not, that lead up to the house?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Who got out of the coach first?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I can't tell; I was led up the steps directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Into what room;

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I believe the first room; we staid there some time.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did I propose to take an airing in the park?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I might go out, but I can't say whether I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: I shall be glad to know if you will swear now, that when you went out of the door to the canal, you did not lay hold of my , and run along with me?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I don't know that I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: It is a pretty strong circumstance; did you go upon the canal before dinner?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes, before dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: What time did you set out from Lord Balti∣more's house?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: About two o'clock.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: What time did you get to Woodcote?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: About four.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: How soon might you dine?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I believe in about half an hour?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Where did you dine?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: In the great dining-room, up one pair of stairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: It was there the first insult was offer∣ed behind the curtain, was it not?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes.
Lord Baltimore, Was it at that time that I talked to you of coming to bed, that I told you it must be that night?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes, he said it must be that night; I got away from him; I don't know that I made him any an∣swer to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you say, upon your oath, that when I talked to you of your coming to bed that night, that you said nothing?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodock.
SP.P: I told him, I would sooner give him my life a hundred times over.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Upon your oath, did not you say, if I would use you faithfully and tenderly, you would let me go to bed to you?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, I said no such thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you not say, some other time might be more convenient.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, I did not.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Where did you drink tea?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Below stairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did not the magnificence of that place strike you?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes, it did; though I would rather have been in the poorest cottage.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did not you say, that you believed that room was finer than any room in the Queen's Palace?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I don't know; possibly I might.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: I think you told us, you eat nothing at supper?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I eat a little bit, but drank nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Then you did not drink several glasses of wine to my health? Who first withdrew to go to bed?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I am not positive.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was it not me?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, I believe it was Mrs. Griffinburgh?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you and Mrs. Harvey go out of the room before me, to go to bed, or after?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Before.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: How long might you be in the room before you was put into my room?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I cannot form any judgment.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Can you recollect your desiring to have a little water to wash your feet?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No? the women proposed it: they talked of my having water to wash my feet, but I re∣fused it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: How soon, after you got into the room, was it, before you observed Dr. Griffinburg in the room?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Not many minutes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was it almost immediately?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I believe almost, but can't exactly say.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: The Doctor, I think, did not inter∣pose in any other manner than by endeavouring to comfort you?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: It is pretty extraordinary, that Dr. Griffinburg should be in the room at all, at such a time; what reason did he give?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: You must ask that of him, Sir; I did not hear him give any reason.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: The two women led you into my room; can you tell, whether the doctor staid, or went away?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, I can't tell.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P:
You have given an account of the womens having put you to bed, of having tucked up the cloaths, and going out of the room; and that in the morning I got up to open the door to you; you
have described the insults offered you; I shall not wound your modesty, to repeat the account of them. —Did you sleep that night?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Not at all that I know.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did I?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: He lay very still the whole night, I don't know whether he was asleep.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You have described yourself as being under dreadful apprehensions, left I should repeat it a second time, why did you not endeavour to save your∣self from that second insult, by endeavouring to get out of bed, and find your way out of the room?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: For this reason; I was in such a fright, I dared not stir hand or foot, for fear he should hear me, and turn to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: In what room did you breakfast, in the morning?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: In the first room below stairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: At what time?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I can't particularly tell that.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You had so far composed yourself, that you had intended to do every thing that was only trivial; to give into my ways, and for that reason you pinned the ribbons on; did not you puss them up ac∣cording to the fashion, that I said they were puffed up too high?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: They are puffed up no higher than are commonly done.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You wore the hat I presume?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Now as to these ribbons, you say they were new made up ribbons, but that they were made up by request of Mrs. Harvey, and the other woman?— Did not you think that breaking in upon your rule?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I did it by compulsion, not by free choice

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you think any force would be used?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: They were very rough with me, and I thought they would be rougher, if I did refuse it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: How long might you wear these vibbons?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I believe all the time.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: At your breast?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes, I believe I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did the two women wear them?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I cannot tell.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Some of the millenery goods were gauze, were they not?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did not you make Mrs. Harvey a present of some gauze?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, I did not.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you recollect, among other a∣musements, your being carried to see the house, and the library. Was there not a book of prints that took your fancy?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes, I did look at them. The Doctor brought them into the room for me to look at, but not at my desire.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You was sometimes in the park, and sometimes on the water?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Once upon the water that day.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: It was useless to you to discover any particular grief for what had happened, and you did not discover it in your countenance?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: In my counenance I did, I was very dull.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You eat and drank at dinner?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: The same at supper?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: There was a gloom then. You was out of spirits, and melancholy; where did you lie that night?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: With Mrs. Harvey.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: It was thought a little strange and extraordinary that I did not want again to lie with you. I think you and all the company laughed heartily upon the occasion: Will you deny that?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes, I will: I was glad he did not lie with me again, but I did not laugh about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was there any laughing upon the occasion?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, not that I know of.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: I think upon the next day you made a visit with Dr. Griffinburgh, to see a poor woman in the house who had broke her leg?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes, Dr. Griffinburg carried me to see her, but not at my desire.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: I believe while he stayed in that room, you went down for your hat and cloak to take a walk in the park?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: We went all in the park together, but this was when we came back.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Then you don't recollect your going out of that room for your hat and cloak, to take a turn with Dr. Griffinburgh; how many times might you have been in the park with Mrs Griffinburg only?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Not above once.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you recollect being on the other side of the pales above the canal with Mrs. Griffinburg only?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: How far might you go with Mrs. Griffinburg only?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: About half a furlong.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: I believe there were a great many workmen laying out a piece of ground by the canal?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: There were.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: And there were workmen altering a stair case?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes, there were, and putting up paper.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Then for the reasons you have given, you did not think right to mention to any body what had happened to you while you were at Woodcote? what day did the visitors come from London?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: The visiters came on Wednesday, two gentlemen and a lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You was sufficiently composed to re∣ceive the lady, and do the honours of the house, to wait on the lady, and shew her the pictures, and what you thought might be agreeable to her?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: She had a mind to see the pictures, and I shewed her the pictures in the room she was in.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did not you assist in preparing the sheets, and putting the things in order for the exhibition?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I believe I did take a needle, in order to do a little of it; not above one bit of thread.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: And you let them a few pins?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, I did not; there was a pincushtion on the ground, I might stick a few of those pins.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was you on the light or dark side after this apparatus was got ready?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: On the dark side. Lord Baltimore was acting the old man part of the time, and another part be came and fat by me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did not you fit upon my knee?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No I did not.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you pledge your credit upon it, that you did not sit upon my knee, and did not kiss me?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Kiss him! no that I did not. Lord Bal∣timore came and crowded himself in the same chair where I sat, that was all; I did not sit on his lap.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Perhaps I was upon your knee!

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, not that I know of.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did not the cords break, and the sheets tumble upon the ground, after the company had taken so much pains?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: I believe notwithstanding the misfor∣tunes you were so much depressed with, you laughed very heartily at it?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I might laugh, but I did not laugh hear∣tily, that I know.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Will you say you did not laugh hear∣tily at it?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I can't say I did not, I don't know that I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You was on the right side to see the exhibition?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes, I was.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was it not amusing?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I thought it an amusement beneath gen∣tlemen of sense to employ themselves in.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did not you laugh at that time?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, Sir, very little.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did not you walk with Mrs. Forrest a∣bout the house, and have some conversation with her?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, I had none.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you recollect her asking you how long you had been in this family?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: She asked me no such thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did not you tell her how long you had been in the family?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Not that I know of.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did not you tell her you had been a twelvemonth in my house?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Upon my oath, I said no such thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: I believe you complained to her that you had come down without a sufficient number of clean things?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Mrs. Harvey told her so.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did not you all dine together, and then come to town together that afternoon?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes, we did in different carriages.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: During the time these people were there, did you betray by your manner or countenance that any thing extraordinary had happened to you?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, I did not; I supported myself as well as I could.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: I believe you told us that Mrs Harvey returned to her own house soon after you returned to London?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I do not know when she went away; I saw no more of her after Friday.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You have given an account of your being introduced to the governess of the young ladies; did you consider it as an innocent thing then, to impose upon these young ladies?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, I did not present myself to the gover∣ness as one come out of the country, but I did not con∣tradict what he said, because he promised in a few days I should see my father.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was not there a bed ordered to be put up for you in Madam Saunier's apartment?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you never understand so?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, not upon that day, on Saturday, when Mrs. Griffinburg said that I must lie in the garret.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Where does Mrs. Saunier lie?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: In the garret.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was it in that garret you was to lie?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, not in that garret.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did not you understand you was to lie in the garret Mrs. Saunier lay in?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, not while I was there; she lay on the same story, but not in that room.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You did not chase to lie there?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, I did not, I was afraid.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You lay with me that night. I un∣derstood this going to bed with me was one of the things; you certainly would not submit to: how came you to make no resistance?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I told him I would not go with him, but I knew he would use force if I did not.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: What time did you get up next morn∣ing?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I don't know: this was on Friday.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: There was a ?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: That was on Saturday.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: I you had with her!

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, none but what I told you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You entered into the general conver∣sation that was going forward!

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You did not, though she was a visiter to them?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, I did not.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: How came you not?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I thought my Lord and all his company were alike, except the young ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you recollect the music master's being there, and I and you pulling one another; I pul∣ling you towards me, and you drawing me to you—some familiarity of that kind?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, he was then come to tell me the news of my father: he took hold of my handkerchief, which I took from him again.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Then you was not anxious when the gown was made, or whether it ever was to be made?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Not the least in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Then as to giving directions how it should be made, the cut of the sleeve, and all such things, you did not concern yourself about?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, I did not.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Not was in a hurry to have it?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, I was not.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Whether you did not press the man∣tua-maker to take care of all things, that you had it next day at dinner!

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, not that I know of.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: As you said it was a thing so indiffe∣rent to you, you must know whether you gave such or∣ders or no?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, I did not; Griffinburg ordered the woman to make the gown next day by dinner, but I did not.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you know the name of the milliner!

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I did not then, but I do now.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Have you not some reason to know it now? Don't you know that that milliner has been ap∣plied to, and told if she comes here she shall lose lier bu∣siness?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I know of no such thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Pray what had you of her?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: A cap and cloak. There were more things brought; I did not take them: there were more things ordered by Mrs. Griffinburg's desire?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: What were they!

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: A mnslin apron and under-petticoats.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: How many?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Two under petticoats.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you mean to swear they were or∣dered by her and not by you?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: She desired I would order what I wanted.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you order them or she?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I did not order them, to my knowledge, but Griffinburg did. I don't care to give a positive an∣swer when I am not positive.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Whether you gave any particular di∣rections how they were to be made?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I can't tell that I did; I did not that I know of.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: I would put it more home to you, that you may recollect; did not you order the miliner to make the two under-petticoats to tie before?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, upon my oath I did not.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was it the mantua-maker or your∣self that made the apron to the gown?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: There was none that I know of.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did not you order an apron to the gown?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Nor stomacher?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: She asked me if I would have a stomacher: I told her I did not care about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you, at the time you went to Mrs. Griffinburg's, know that there was any disturbance about you?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, I did not; I went to meet my father.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You was very anxious to get away from my Lord, and glad to take any opportunity?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: How did you go to Mrs. Griffinburg?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: In a coach.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was it my coach or a hackney coach?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: That I don't know.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P:
You was quick enough in pointing
out the difference between a hackney coach and gen∣tleman's in o former case; I desire you would tell now?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I looked and think I saw a number, but am not certain.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was there any body in the coach ex∣cept yourself, Mrs. Griffinburg, and the child?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, not that I know of.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: What age is the child of?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: About eight years old.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Mrs. Griffinburg has not got a yard with great gates before her door, has she?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: She got out of the coach first, did she not.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did the child go out before you, or after you?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I can't tell.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Now you had got into the open street, why did not you get away into the first shop that was open for you?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Because of this; I did not know but the servants were there; and I did not think of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Consider, you was hazarding every thing against nothing: If your father was there, still you would have been safe if you had gone off; if your father was not there, you would have been safe, and yet it never occurred to you when in a public street, with no soul but old Mrs. Griffinburg and a child, whe∣ther that was not a time to run away. I ask you ano∣ther thing: Did not this coach stop two or three doors from Mrs. Griffinburg's house?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You then had to walk to her house?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, the coach went on again.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: What time of the day was this?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: About two o'clock.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You then was in the public street, exceeding desireous of getting away from me, and ne∣ver thinking that was the time to run away.—What room did you go into at Mrs. Griffinburg's?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: A back parlour on the ground floor.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Your father was not there?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did not Mrs. Griffinburg go down into the kitchen to give her orders about the dinner?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: She went down and made the door fast after her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: I desire to have a plain answer, with∣out seeing so much of the consequence: I desire to know whether she did not go out of the room and go down into the kitchen, and leave you and Miss Fanny alone?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Serjeant Leigh.
SP.P: She explains every question you ask her, and if you take the answer, you must let her explain it.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I believe she might go once or twice. She went out two or three times; she always kept the door fast, and kept amusing me with accounts that my father was coming.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: One would have thought such a young woman as you are could have got out of the parlour into the street. How many hours did you stay there?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I can't tell how many.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore
SP.P: What part of the afternoon did you set out for the Crown and Magpye?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: About nine o'clock. If I had tried to es∣cape from Griffinburg's I believe I could not.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: What time did Mr. Morris the trades∣man come?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: He was brought to carry the letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did he carry the letter?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did he not come back and tell you he could not find your father at home?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Then you wrote another letter?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes, I did, and sent it to my father.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: That letter was your own letter, wrote by yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes, it was.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did not you come to the door to Mr. Morris, and give him that letter to carry to Mrs. Berry, the landlady of the house where your father lives? You speak of the boy's leading the way into the room?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Had you any refreshment.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: We had a bottle of wine.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was my body in the bar?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I cannot , my Lord had hold of my hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: How far might that tavern be from your father's?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: The length of the Minories, and a little way up that street.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Had you never been by that house?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes. I should know it if I was to see it again.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: And then you was afraid to attempt to get away because I had hold of your hand?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Who brought in the wine.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: A little boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was any bell in the room?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: The bell was rung, and the boy went backwards and forewards.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Whether, during the time you was there, you was not more than once left with no body but the child and the neice.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No: Lord Baltimore was in the room all the time; he never went out.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: I believe the tradesman came back, and went back with you in the coach to Dr. Griffin∣burg's? did he not?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: He got out of the coach to go to Sir John Fielding's?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: So I afterwards understood, to see about Harvey.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was not his business to fetch your fa∣ther to Dr. Griffinburg?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I don't know any such thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: One of Sir John Fielding's clerks came with a card, you said; you did not give an answer to it, but put the card in my hand, and I said you should not go; then you desired your father might come there. Recollect yourself, and tell me whether that is the ac∣count you stand by? You swore, upon receiving the card, you did not say, I will not go to Sir John Fielding's?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Not that I know of; I did not say any such thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Recollect yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I cannot recollect that I said I would not go.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You recollected with as great exact∣ness as ever I heard a witness?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: In giving in my evidence, I gave it in e∣very thing as far as I could recollect.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Whether, when the card was brought to you, you did not immediately say, without putting it into my hand, that you would not go to Sir John's?

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Can you say positively one way or other?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I cannot.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: I think you say, when the coach came back again to my house, that there was a great mob, and you called out to them, to let them come in?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: When did you first hear of this thing they call the Habeas Corpus?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I heard the word Habeas Corpus, when they were talking in their own language.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: What did you understand to be the reason of your going to Lord Mansfield's?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I concluded that my friends were taking some step; and that carrying me to Lord Mansfield's was something done by my friends in opposition to Lord Baltimore; but I did not know that Lord Mansfield was a magistrate.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: When you was first told you must go before Lord Mansfield, did not you say to me that you was satisfied, and would not leave me?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, I never said so.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You spoke of a letter you wrote to your father upon the occasion?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: I believe there was something remark∣able in that letter?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes, I put a little bill in it, that my fa∣ther might know it came from me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: This letter was wrote that day before you went to Lord Mansfield: how long before you went, had you finished this letter?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: It was just then out of my hands before. Mr. Warts came in the first time.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You express in that letter the good treatment you have received from me, and desire they would make no more disturbance?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I did not know what to say, in order that he might let it go. I wrote it by his order, in a manner contrary to my heart, because I was afraid he would not otherwise let it go; and because I was afraid my father would be afraid to come.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: So then you really and truely wrote it against your own sentiments?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes, I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You have mentioned Mr. Brown's be∣ing there; was it before Mr. Watts, or after?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Before.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Before the first time?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was you not writing a letter before Mr. Srown came?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Had you any conversation with Mr. Brown. or me, about the habeas corpus?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: They were a talking, but I paid no re∣gard to what they said.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did not Mr. Brown ask you, whether you was of age or not?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: not that I know of.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did not you tell him you was more than of age considerably, twenty six?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I do not know that I said such a word, I do not know that Mr. Brown asked me such a question?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did not Mr. Brown tell you, you was at your own liberty?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: And you did not express a satisfacti∣on at it?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You went with Mr. Brown and me, in his carriage, did not you? did not you come to him before you finished your letter, and he desired you to go back, and finish it?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I gave it Lord Baltimore, and he shew∣ed it to Brown.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was you desired to finish it?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes, Lord Baltimore desired it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Mr. Brown then went out, did he not?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: That I do not know.

SP.SPEAKER: Lood Baltimore.
SP.P: When did he return back again; before or after Mr. Watts served the Habeas Corpus?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: After.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: When you went to Lord Mansfield's, what did you do with your things, had not you locked them up in the garret, and got the key?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I carried away the key of the garret, but did not know that I had it, till a week afterwards.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Had not you twenty guineas of me to pay for them?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, he gave me thirteen guineas on Christ∣mas Day, when I was introduced to the rest of the family.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: I did not give you money to pay for them that morning?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You have given us an account of what passed before Lord Mansfield, and that he asked you if you had not been brought to my house against your consent, and you said twice quite against my will; that he asked you if you was of age, and you told him yes?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: He was going to ask me something, I said, I was more than of age.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you not tell my Lord Mansfield, that you knew he had no power, as you was more than of age, to oblige you to go back to your father? After having said you was taken away, and detained against your consent, you told Lord Mansfield, that you was willing as things were as they were, to go back to my house. Now, this is very mysterious, and unintelligi∣ble, that you should tell this gentleman that you was brought before to be got out of my hands, that you would go back again with me?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I did not know what Lord Mansfield's power was.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You knew your friends had brought you there, to get you out of my hands; you was with Lord Mansfield, and only another gentleman with him; have you no better reason to give the jury for not tel∣ling him you was unwilling to go with me again, than the not knowing Lord Mansfield's authority. Now, when you was sent to your friends, did you immediately ask that question, was that the first?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I am not positive that that was the first.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you express to your friends no sort of inclination to go back with me.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I expressed an inclination, by which they found I did not know Lord Mansfield's power, and they acquainted me with it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: I ask you, if when you came to your friends, you did not express an inclination to go back with me?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I had no inclination to go back.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you say nothing to your friends of being desireous to go back?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, not that I know of.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: No, nothing of your being better a∣ble to supply them, and provide for them?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I can't now tell what I said; they found that I did not know his power.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: I ask you one more question, whether you did not say, even to Mr. Watts, after you left Lord Mansfield's, that you was willing to go back to my house?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, no such thing; and all my friends can testify the contrary.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Who went to bed first, the last night you lay with me?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: In what bed?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: In Lord Baltimore's bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Pray, was any body in the room be∣sides me and you?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: He went out.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You went into the bed, when I was not in the room.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I did. He came up afterwards; Mrs. Griffinburg's neice was in the room.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: So you went and undressed yourself, and went to my bed, and I came to you.—I think you said, it was on the promise that I should not meddle with you; though you say I had broke that promise the last time I came to bed to you; yet you yourself got into my bed.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I did so, because I was afraid he would kill me that night, if I did not.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Did you express to your friends any desire or inclination towards Lord Baltimore?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock,
SP.P: I can't tell exactly what I said; they said, Lord Mansfield had power to deliver me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Did you, at that time, tell your father, or sisters, that you wanted te go back again to Lord Balti∣more?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No I did not.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: You said, Lord Baltimore had promised to send for your father in the morning.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: He said, it was done with a view to get my father to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: What made you write so foreign to your heart?

SP.SPEAKER: S Woodcock.
SP.P: Because I knew he would not let it go, if it was not wrote so; and my father would not come, if he was not pacified.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: At the time that Lord Mansfield asked you, if you was of age, and you told him you was—Do you re∣collect that he said, you was at liberty to go where you pleased.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: He said something I can't tell what.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: When you went out of one room into the o∣ther, to your friends, who began the conversation first, you or they? Did they know, by what you had said to Lord Mansfield, that you wanted to go back to Lord Baltimore's.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: She had not seen them before; they knew not what had passed between her and Lord Mansfield.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Did you tell them what had passed between you and Lord Mansfield?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I don't remember that I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: When you found Lord Mansfield had power to set you at liberty, then you told them you had been violated.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, not in my Lord Mansfield's house; As I remember, one of my sisters asked me if I had been ruined, I said yes:

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Now with relation to ruining, that is a sort of general term; it may be with or without your consent. —Did you tell her whether it was without your consent?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: She asked, if with my consent? I said, No, without my consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: What was your reason of not applying to my Lord Mansfield, and afterwards applying to Justice Fielding?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Woodcock.
SP.P: I was so overjoyed at being at liberty, that I thought of nothing else.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Baker.
SP.P: Do you remember a woman coming to your shop for a pair of ruffles?—Do you remember one Mrs. Johnson?

SP.SPEAKER: E. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes, and Lord Baltimore followed her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Baker.
SP.P: Do you remember his coming several times?

SP.SPEAKER: E. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes, I was at home three times when Lord Baltimore came.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Baker.
SP.P: Was you at home when he bought some ribbons?

SP.SPEAKER: E. Woodcock.
SP.P:
No, I was not then; Mrs. Harvey came on Monday the 14th of December, and desired to know whether we had any flowered gauze; I took down the
book and shewed her: she bespoke a pair of double ruf∣fles, and ordered them to be done the next day by one or two o'clock. She accordingly came, and paid for them; and ordered my sister to bring some lace with her (to put on a child's cap) to Curtain-row where she said she lived. The next day my sister went, about half an hour after four o'clock; that was on Wednesday. My sister did not come home all night; we were very much frightened; we sat up till one o'clock; then a let∣ter came that she was at a friend's house; that she was safe and well. A porter brought it; it was not my sis∣ter's hand-writing. This was Wednesday the 16th of December.

SP.SPEAKER: E. Woodcock.
SP.P: That is it. There was no name, nor the place she was at. I asked the man who brought it, where he had it. He said he came out of Whitechapel, and then he went away. This letter said she would come home at twelve o'clock next day. I sat till that time, and was very uneasy. I then went to all her friends she used to go to, to enquire after her. The first night we had any account of her, was a week after she had been gone away.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Baker.
SP.P: What methods did you take to get at her?

SP.SPEAKER: E. Woodcock.
SP.P: We went to see after Mrs. Harvey, but could not find the place; nobody knew such a woman. Mr. Davis came and told me he believed he had found something of it out. I went accordingly to Mrs. Har∣vey's; the maid came to the door; I asked for Mrs. Har∣vey, if she was at home. She said, no. I asked her how long she had been gone out. She said ever since that night week. I asked if any body went with her. She said a young lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Baker.
SP.P: Then from that you traced ont that Mrs. Harvey was gone out with a young woman?

SP.SPEAKER: E. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes; and by the description of her dress I knew it was my sister?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Baker.
SP.P: Do you know any thing of your own knowledge between that time and when you saw your sister at Lord Mansfield's?

SP.SPEAKER: E. Woodcock.
SP.P: We followed this Mrs. Harvey: she came to her own house on Christmas-day at night, and was taken up.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Baker.
SP.P:
There was an Habeas Corpus taken out,
and you saw your sister at Lord Mansfield's how did she appear?

SP.SPEAKER: E. Woodcock.
SP.P: She appeared almost out of her senses. We had a great piece of work to persuade her that Lord Mansfield had power to deliver her. When I went to her, I asked her if she was married. She said, no. We told her she might now get away, Lord Mansfield could deli∣ver her. We had a great piece of work to persuade her he had power to deliver her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Baker.
SP.P: Did she express any desire of going back to Lord Baltimore's?

SP.SPEAKER: E. Woodcock.
SP.P: No, but great desire of going with us: only she was afraid Lord Mansfield had not power to de∣liver her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Baker.
SP.P: Did she express this more than once?

SP.SPEAKER: E. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes, several times.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Baker.
SP.P: She did go away, did she not?

SP.SPEAKER: E. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes, very much rejoiced.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Baker.
SP.P: Do you remember any thing that passed when she went away?

SP.SPEAKER: E. Woodcock.
SP.P: No; she went with Mr. Davis and several others, I was left behind.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
