SP.P: As you took this lady's face, you will be able to tell us, whether it was a chearful face, or whether in tears?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: She never cried all the time. No, a figure that would cry would not stand in that position, and I could not go on. She was very willing to stay in that positi∣on. She was drawn in this position (describing it.) lean∣ing her head upon her hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was there any appearance of concern or sorrow about her?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: She was rather chearful she behaved with the same ease that every body did.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: She said something of your having carried a letter?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: That was a letter I received from a gentleman a fortnight before; who sent me a letter to send to Lord Baltimore; which I did: and that day the gentleman had been to me, and said he desired to speak to his Lord∣ship, but he would not go to his house: and he desired me to let him know; it was a tall gentleman in a brown coat.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: How came he to find you out?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Lord Baltimore told me a gentleman should come to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did this lady say any thing to you a∣bout your having brought any letter from her father or friends?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith,
SP.P: No; this lady in conversation asked what this gentleman was. I told her he was drest in a brown coat.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Well, Mr. Smith, your account is a pretty strange one; you have been acquainted with Lord Bal∣timore a good while, have you not?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Next May, six years, I have had the honour to know his Lordship; and have had the honour to work for his Lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: What day of the month was this you drew the lady's picture?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: It was on the 17th or 18th of December last.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: What brought you to Lord Baltimore's house that day?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Upon that day he sent for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Did he let you know what he wanted you for?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I thought he had sent for me to draw a pic∣ture: and I afterwards saw the truth of it. His Lord∣ship sent often for me to draw pictures.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: And yet when you came there Lord Balti∣more lent you his pencil?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: When I was there I told him I had not got a pencil in my pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: So then you was sent for to draw a picture and yet you went without your materials: how came you, to be in such a hurry?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: He sent to me to come directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: And so you was in such a hurry that you left your pencil in the other pocket?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: That is natural for people when they change their cloths.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: What not to take the things out of their pocket?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: The servant told me my Lord Baltimore want∣ed to see me directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Well, and then you said, you thought that he was in a hurry; and you went and left these materi∣als at home: that is the fact, I think. Now when you came to Lord Baltimore's there was some conversation passed relating to a letter. Tell my Lord and the jury what the letter was he asked you about.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: The letter I had wrote to my Lord from a gen∣tleman that had been with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: What gentleman was he?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I don't know.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: How did he send it you?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: My Lord told me that such a gentleman should come to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Now see if I understand you. A fortnight before this my Lord told you, that a gentleman should come to you; but he did not come, but sent you a let∣ter. Did you send that letter?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I sent it to my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Then it was a letter directed to your hands —to be given to Lord Baltimore; and this you was in∣formed of a fortnight before?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: This gentleman came just that day.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: And this was the very day the man came with the message to Lord Baltimore, and just before that this letter was brought to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: No, this letter was brought a fortnight before.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: When was it delivered to Lord Baltimore?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: The instant I had received it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Then had you any further directions in it?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: No, that gentleman called upon me on that ve∣ry day, about four or five o'clock in the evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Cox.
SP.P: What did he say to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: He said, that he wanted to speak to his Lord∣ship. I asked if he would go to his Lordship? He said, he would not go, but desired me to let my Lord know he had been with me; and so I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Did you do it by message, or go to his house?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I sent a letter in French, that a gentleman that I did not know had been at my house.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Now all this happened before you went to my Lord the same day, and yet you thought it was all about drawing a picture?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: My Lord asked me what sort of a man he was? And the lady asked me what was the colour of his coat? I said, a brown coat.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Was that the only question she asked you?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Only then about the colour of the coat the man had on that called upon you that day. She said no∣thing about the size of the man, whether taller or shorter, did she?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Not a single word.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: And this was in consquence of a letter that was sent a fortnight before. What is your name?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: My name is Smith.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Where do you live?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I live in Dufour's Court, Broad-street Carnaby market.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: What conversation had you at Lord Balti∣more's that day about this man in the brown coat?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: My Lord asked me whether he was an old or a young man? I said, an old man in a brown coat.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Now was it an old man in a brown coat?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Yes, and a very tall man.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Did he ask you that question in the presence of the lady, or behind her back, in French or English?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: No, in plain English.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Did my Lord say any thing to you in French?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Yes he did speak some words in French, some∣thing relating to what had passed in the news papers.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: What is the business you generally do for me?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I take designs for my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You being a foreigner, do not I often talk to you in your own language?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Cox.
SP.P: You say you was present when the lady drank tea, will you, upon your oath, say you saw her drink one drop of tea?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: She was very merry in conversation as the rest were.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: You was there at supper; Did she drink e∣very body's health?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: She drank my Lord's health, and she drank to every body round.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: In what liquor?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I believe small beer.
I am Lord Baltimore's laundry-maid. I was at Lord Baltimore's house in December; I was there before they went to Woodcote.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you know in what bed Mrs. Har∣vey used to lie?

SP.SPEAKER: Harrison.
SP.P: In the next room to my Lord's bedchamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore
SP.P: I would ask you, if you know any person that lay with her there?

SP.SPEAKER: Harrison.
SP.P: I suppose Sarah Woodcock did.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was there the appearance of two per∣sons in Mrs Harvey's bed?

SP.SPEAKER: Harison.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Who made the fire in this room?

SP.SPEAKER: Harrison.
SP.P: I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you ever see any people in bed together in that room?

SP.SPEAKER: Harrison.
SP.P: I have seen Mrs. Harvey and Miss Wood∣cock in bed together, I cannot say how often; I have seen them every morning in bed till the went to Wood∣cote, all but the first morning after she came. I have heard them converse there.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: I would ask you whether you ever saw any acts of civility between Mrs. Harvey ands Mis Wood∣cock?

SP.SPEAKER: Harrison.
SP.P: I have always seen her very merry.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you see her perpetually in tears, lamenting and pining?

SP.SPEAKER: Harrison.
SP.P: No, never; I always saw her laughing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you often see her in the day-time?

SP.SPEAKER: Harrison.
SP.P: I did: Mrs. Harvey used to dress her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: And what did she use to do for her?

SP.SPEAKER: Harrison.
SP.P: I have only seen her comb her hair, I saw her do that twice.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Baker.
SP.P: Who is this Mrs. Harvey? Did she live in this house? Did she lie there before this girl came?

SP.SPEAKER: Harrison.
SP.P: No she did not.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Baker.
SP.P: Then they came together?

SP.SPEAKER: Harrison.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Baker.
SP.P: You went to make the fire the first morning, where was the girl?

SP.SPEAKER: Harrison.
SP.P: She was in the room with Mrs. Harvey: they were both up.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Baker.
SP.P: Where was Mrs. Griffinburg?

SP.SPEAKER: Harrison.
SP.P: In the room too.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Baker.
SP.P: I ask you upon your oath, was not Griffinburg in the room the next night?

SP.SPEAKER: Harrison.
SP.P: No, she was not. On Thursday night and Wednesday night she lay below stairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Baker.
SP.P: So in the morning before you went to make the fire, Mrs. Griffinbugh had got up stairs, and was in the room with them?

SP.SPEAKER: Harrison.
SP.P: She went up to shew me the room. I had been there almost a twelvemonth, but did not know they were there; Mrs. Griffinburg told me I was to go in that way.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Baker.
SP.P:
If I understand you right, you told me
you found there the two prisoners and Miss Woodcock. Pray did Dr. Griffinburg lie in this house!

SP.SPEAKER: Harrison
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Baker.
SP.P: Pray what was Mrs. Griffinburg in this house?

SP.SPEAKER: Harrison.
SP.P: Housekeeper.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Baker.
SP.P: Pray did the young woman bring any cloths into the house?

SP.SPEAKER: Harrison.
SP.P: Not that I know of.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Baker.
SP.P: When did the change her cloths?

SP.SPEAKER: Harrison.
SP.P: After the came from Woodcote.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Baker.
SP.P: Did the bring any linen with her?

SP.SPEAKER: Harrison.
SP.P: Not that I know of.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Baker.
SP.P: When was the first time she had any clean linen?

SP.SPEAKER: Harrison.
SP.P: I can't say.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Baker.
SP.P: Who did the have it of?

SP.SPEAKER: Harrison.
SP.P: Mrs. Griffinburg.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Baker.
SP.P: Now I ask you if that was not the Monday morning, the day she went to Woodcote?

SP.SPEAKER: Harrison.
SP.P: I can't say the day when it was.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Baker.
SP.P: The girl was always a laughing, constant∣ly, was she not?

SP.SPEAKER: Harrison.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Baker.
SP.P: What, whether you spoke to her or not? Did she walk all about the house?

SP.SPEAKER: Harrison.
SP.P: Yes, I saw her in my Lord's bedchamber the Friday before she went to Woodcote.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Baker.
SP.P: What, never go out all the time?

SP.SPEAKER: Harrison.
SP.P: No, not that I know of.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Baker.
SP.P: What, did she shut up herself in the house?

SP.SPEAKER: Harrison.
SP.P: She might have gone out if she would.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Baker.
SP.P: Then you don't know the reason of Mrs Harvey's staying in the house at this particular time? You don't know where she liv'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Harrison.
SP.P: No, I did not.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did not Griffinburg go up with you into the room?

SP.SPEAKER: Harrison.
SP.P: Yes, she did; and was giving me directions where to light the fire.
I am cook to Lord Baltimore.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Pray what apartment did you lie in?

SP.SPEAKER: Mitchell.
SP.P: Over the room in which my Lord lay.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Where did Mrs. Harvey lie?

SP.SPEAKER: Mitchell.
SP.P: In the same room Miss Woodcock lay in: my room is partly over my Lord's room, and partly over Mrs. Harvey's.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Pray have you ever heard any conver∣sation, or noise?

SP.SPEAKER: Mitchell.
SP.P: I have heard laughing, talking, and merri∣ment.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Then you heard it often?

SP.SPEAKER: Mitchell.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: What when Miss Woodcock has been there?

SP.SPEAKER: Mitchell.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you ever hear any noise or crying out?

SP.SPEAKER: Mitchell.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: This was in London?

SP.SPEAKER: Mitchell.
SP.P: Yes, in London: all that I heard was merri∣ment and laughing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
SP.P: Did you ever see Miss Woodcock?

SP.SPEAKER: Mitchell.
SP.P: No; but I know she was there. I could di∣stinguish three voices.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
SP.P: You say that if there had been any crying out, or noise below, you must have heard it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mitchell.
SP.P: I am sure of that; I have heard laughing and talking, but never heard any crying out: I could hear every thing that mov'd or stirr'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Can you hear the curtains draw?

SP.SPEAKER: Mitchell.
SP.P: I could; I could have distinguished voices in the room; or if any body was to speak or stir the fire, I could hear it.
I am one of Lord Baltimore's postilions.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was you one of the drivers when I went to Woodcote?

SP.SPEAKER: Mackdonald.
SP.P: Yes; I drove the wheel-horses.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Who was in the carriage?

SP.SPEAKER: Mackdonald.
SP.P:
There was Dr. Griffinburg, his wife, my Lord, and two women more; I took notice of the peo∣ple
that went into the carriage; they went in very chear∣fully; I observed nothing in particular; it was a post coach with four horses.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: What glasses are there?

SP.SPEAKER: Mackdonald.
SP.P: There are sore glasses and side glasses.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Can you tell which way we sat?

SP.SPEAKER: Mackdonald.
SP.P: His Lordship and two women sat together; they rode with their faces to the horses.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was there not a little accident hap∣pened at setting out?

SP.SPEAKER: Mackdonald.
SP.P: The porter forgot to fasten one part of the gate; the wind blew the gate to, and the hind wheel laid hold of it: I expected the carriage was torn all to pieces, but I found it was the gate, and as soon as I could stop the carriage, I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: How long did you stop?

SP.SPEAKER: Mackdonald.
SP.P: For about a minute or two; there was a great many people got round the carriage; the glasses were up.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Upon the accident happening, were they not let down?

SP.SPEAKER: Mackdonald.
SP.P: One of the side glasses was; we went on to Woodcote, over Westminster bridge, at the usual rate.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Had you no particular orders to hurry?

SP.SPEAKER: Mackdonald.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Could you, who was the nearest pos∣tilion, hear the voices of the people in the carriage as you went along?

SP.SPEAKER: Mackdonald.
SP.P: I heard a good deal of mirth and merri∣ment, langhing, and so on; they seemed all very chear∣ful: they arrived at Woodcote between two and three o'clock.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: What time did you set out?

SP.SPEAKER: Mackdonald.
SP.P: A little after eleven.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you speak with certainty as to the time?

SP.SPEAKER: Mackdonald.
SP.P: Not to a moment; I speak to the best of my knowledge, I saw his Lordship get out of the coach, and this Brange woman gave him her hand, and he led her in.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did she look as if she was a prisoner?

SP.SPEAKER: Mackdonald.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you see them afterwards?

SP.SPEAKER: Mackdonald.
SP.P: No, I went to take care of my horses.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you not wait at table?

SP.SPEAKER: Mackdonald.
SP.P: I never waited at his Lordship's table. They came back again in the same manner.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
SP.P: What was it o'clock?

SP.SPEAKER: Mackdonald.
SP.P: Not more than three. It was more than full day-light.
I am one of Lord Baltimore's footmen.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you remember going to Woodcote?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Who went there, and in what man∣ner?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: It was my Lord's own post coach and four there was my Lord, Dr. Griffinburg, Mrs. Griffinburg, Mrs. Harvey, and Miss Woodcock.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: What time did you set out from Lon∣don?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: At about half an hour after eleven or therea∣bout.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you remember any accident that happened as you were coming out, with one of the gates?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: The wind blew it to; it was very near over∣turning; that it caused a stoppage for about a couple of minutes, and a great many people were passing and re∣passing. I went behind the coach to Woodcote.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Pray which way did the coach go out of town?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: It went over Westminster bridge.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Perhaps as you was behind, you can tell the behaviour of the company?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: I frequently heard the company langhing, and very merry.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was either of the glasses let down?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: The near glass was let down when the accident happen'd at the gate.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Then you went the whole journey be∣hind the coach.

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you hear laughing at different times?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: I did, when I was behind the coach.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Who went in first?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: I think Sarah Woodcock; she got in by herself.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: When came to Woodcote, do you remember how they go out?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: I opened the coach door, and his Lordship got out first, and then Sarah Woodcock: his Lordship, I be∣lieve, offered his hand, and she leaned her hand upon his arm; I am not certain: then all the company went up the slight of steps into the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Where did you go to?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: Into his Lordship's parlour.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you wait at dinner?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Who sat at dinner that day?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: His Lordship, Dr. and Mrs. Griffinburg, Mrs. Harvey and Sarah Woodcock.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did she eat any thing at dinner?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did she drink any thing?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: Yes—Wine and water.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did she behave, or not, as the rest of the company did?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: I could see no manner of difference.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did she appear in distress then she got out of the coach at Woodcore? Did you see her at any time crying, and in distress?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was you not upon the water?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: Yes, I was.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Who was there?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: His Lordship, Mrs. Griffinburg, Mrs. Harvey, and Sarah Woodcock.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Who conducted the boat?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: His Lordship and I rowed it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you remember the day that some company came down?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: Yes; it was Wednesday the 23d. They came after dinner: Sarah Woodcock drank tea with the rest of the company: I waited at table: Mr. Smith was one.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: What, Smith the painter?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: No, a Geman, and a gentleman and lady be∣sides, whose names I did not know

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did she behave at tea as the rest of the company did?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: Yes; I did not see the least sign of discontent.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did she cut and drink at supper?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: She did; she generally drank wine and water.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: I believe next day we went to town!

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: Yes they did; I went to town on horseback.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: We supped there on Wednesday, did we not? Where did the company breakfast?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: They breakfasted in the parlour; Miss Wood∣cock was there.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: How was the time taken up?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: I don't know. They walked about the park when they had a mind, and came into the house when they had a mind, and when they pleased. On Tuesday morning after breakfast, they went upon the water.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did Miss Woodcock breakfast on Tuesday morning with the family?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: Yes. I remember seeing them get into the carriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you remember how they got into the coach?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: Sarah Woodcock got in first, and had no as∣sistance, to my knowledge.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was you near enough the carriage to see the behaviour of the people in the inside of it?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: No; I was on horseback as I returned.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: During the time she was in town, or at Woodcote, did you ever see her in tears?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: I never did.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Were there any doors locked, or the like?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: No, the doors were all open.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Were there any directions given to the servants to stop her, in cafe the went out?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: No, not by Lord Baltimore or any body else.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was you at Lord Mansfields? I only ask you to one particular fact; did you see any little in∣timacy between any body after the thing was over?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: A young man laid hold of her by the arm, and just as they got down to the second step, he kissed her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: How did she behave?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: I stood at the bottom of the steps.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Who was the man that kiss'd her!

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: They told me his name was Davis.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Who spoke, or looked, did any thing to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: When the down by m, the and looked me and smiled at me,

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: You say she got first into the coach, did you know her.

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: I have seen her person. I saw her looking out at the window, but I never waited on her in London. I waited at table at breakfast, dinner and supper.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: You are employed to wait at table, and yet you say you never saw this girl but at Lord Baltimore's window: This was severe weather, had you been used to parties of pleasure on the water in such severe weather?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: What fort of a vessel is this?

SP.SPEAKER: Potter.
SP.P: A large boat. My Lord has built a fort of a cabin in one of them. The first day they were in the open boat, and in the cabin the second day.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: What are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Perry.
SP.P: I live in Fore-street, St. Giles's, Cripplegate. I was at Lord Baltimore's on the 21st of December last; I was going to Dr. Griffinburg to recommend a friend of mine to him: when we came to Dr. Griffinburg's house, I went from thence to my Lord Baltimore's, and when Mrs. Vergen my friend and I came within about ten yards of the porter's lodge, the coach came out with four bay horses; the coach took part of the gate away; the coach stopt some little time; I was pretty near the coach; I saw five people in it; I saw Dr. Griffinburg in the coach, and pulled of my hat to him, and wished him a good ride, I saw my Lord and the other woman, I do'nt mean the young woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you hear any call for assistance?

SP.SPEAKER: Perry.
SP.P: There was a great number of people, ten or a dozen, passing and repassing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did not you wonder that nobody call∣ed out?

SP.SPEAKER: Perry.
SP.P: I was surprised, that from the danger the coach was in, that nobody screamed out that was in the coach.

DIV1.P:
I was at Lord Baltimore's on the 21st of December last, and saw an accident with the coach, it ran against the gate, and stopt about a minute; I looked into the
coach, there were five people in it; I did not hear any body call out in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Batilmore.
SP.P: Were there any other people there?

SP.SPEAKER: Vergen.
SP.P: Yes, several; I was near the coach, so near that if any body had spoke I should have heard them.
I am a butler (in the country) to my Lord Baltimore.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you remember the coach coming to Woodcote?

SP.SPEAKER: Stanger.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Who were in it?

SP.SPEAKER: Stanger.
SP.P: Lord Baltimore, Dr. Griffinburg, Mrs. Har∣vey, and Miss Woodcock.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Who opened the coach door?

SP.SPEAKER: Stanger.
SP.P: The footman that came down with it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you remember their geting out of the coach?

SP.SPEAKER: Stanger.
SP.P: I don't know who handed her out; they went up the lawn into the parlour; my Lord came back on the lawn, and Miss Woodcock came after him; she got hold of his arm and run into the house; that was before dinner; and she sat down to dinner, and always drank first his Lordship's health; she drank tea, and was very merry and chearful. I attended his Lordship in his bedchamber; I warmed his bed and undressed him; Dr. Griffinburg came in; I heard the other door open, but who opened it I don't know.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you hear any thing said upon that occasion?

SP.SPEAKER: Stanger.
SP.P: Dr. Griffinburg was in his Lordship's room, and went round to the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you hear any thing in the other room, of any noise, or outcry, or complaint?

SP.SPEAKER: Stanger.
SP.P: No. On Tuesday morning I said the cloth for breakfast; Mrs Harvey and Miss Woodcock came down together; they were very merry and chearful.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Were there any marks of deep distress?

SP.SPEAKER: Stanger.
SP.P: Not any.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore
SP.P: Could you have then conceived by her appearance she had been ravished the night before?

SP.SPEAKER: Stanger.
SP.P:
No; the always had coee between twelve and one o'clock; on Tuesday morning I saw Mrs. Grif∣finburg and Miss Woodcock come out of the room; she ran down the airs after her; she jumped down and
catched hold of Mrs. Griffinburg's arm, little piece of water, and was very merry.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Some company came on Wednesday, did they not?

SP.SPEAKER: Stanger.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you remember the entertainment of that evening?

SP.SPEAKER: Stanger.
SP.P: It was a kind of magic lanthorn; and Miss Woodcock, for one, downed on her knees upon the car∣pet, sewing these table-cloaths together, to make one piece of it, and she laughed at it, and was extremely merry about it, more so than any one: the cord broke, and we were obliged to put it up again; Miss Woodcock laughed very much at that, more particularly than any body; she came into my pantry one day, and admired the paintings there.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was there any orders given for re∣straining her?

SP.SPEAKER: Stanger.
SP.P: No, I never saw her but she had her liberty to go where she pleased.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Were there not several workmen a∣bout?

SP.SPEAKER: Stanger.
SP.P: There were forty or fifty workmen about the house and park: she might have gone away, I dare say, if she chose it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Baker.
SP.P: You know Mrs. Harvey; was she ever at Woodcote before this?

SP.SPEAKER: Stanger.
SP.P: No. Miss Woodcock was the merriest always, she laughed surprisingly, and was always the merriest of the company.

SP.SPEAKER: Noble.
SP.P: I am land steward to Lord Baltimore.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you remember my coming down on the 21st of December to Woodcote?

SP.SPEAKER: Noble.
SP.P: I saw my Lord's carriage coming, but I did not see him get out; he staid to the 24th; there was a young lady with him, one Miss Woodcock; I remember to have seen her there very well; once saw her with Mrs. Grif∣finburg a furlong, at least, from the house in the park; the next time I saw her along with Mrs. Harvey and Mrs. Griffinbugh, and they walked down to the bottom of the lawn, and turned round the paes at the bottom.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Had you any workmen employed then?

SP.SPEAKER: Noble.
SP.P: Yes; I believe we had ten men at work on the outside, and ten on the inside of the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did they walk near where these men were?

SP.SPEAKER: Noble.
SP.P: They walked so nigh that they could talk to the workmen.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you remember any thing of some Italian shades represented there one night?

SP.SPEAKER: Noble.
SP.P: Yes; I do; they were sewed together; I was not present at the time they were sewing; I put them up; when I was drawing it up, the rope broke, and it dropt; Miss Woodcock laughed very heartily, and the lady that sat next to her. I was coming out of the great room that evening, and saw Miss Woodcock warming her feet in a room by herself; that was on Wednesday night the 23d,

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you see her often when she was down?

SP.SPEAKER: Noble.
SP.P: I saw her many times, and she seemed to be ve∣ry chearful and easy.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you ever hear of any orders given to confine her?

SP.SPEAKER: Noble.
SP.P: No, none at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Could she not have gone out of the house as well as any body else?

SP.SPEAKER: Noble.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: That seat is not far from Epsom?

SP.SPEAKER: Noble.
SP.P: About a mile we call it; it is but half a mile from our park.

DIV1.P: I live at Woodcote; I am my Lord's house-maid at Woodcote; I remember Miss Woodcock being there; I was there all the time she was there.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: How did she behave?

SP.SPEAKER: Chandler.
SP.P: Very well; the same as the rest of the ladies

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was she dejected, or in good spirits?

SP.SPEAKER: Chandler.
SP.P: I observed no difference; she was under no restraint; I saw her on the lawn on the Monday, the day she came.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Who was walking with her?

SP.SPEAKER: Chandler.
SP.P: His Lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Before or after dinner?

SP.SPEAKER: Chandler.
SP.P: Before dinner, as soon as they came down.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: In what manner did she walk with him?

SP.SPEAKER: Chandler.
SP.P: She was close by him; I did not observe whether she had held of him or not, but she seemed ve∣ry merry and chearful.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You warmed the beds there I believe?

SP.SPEAKER: Chandler.
SP.P: I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Whose bed did you warm?

SP.SPEAKER: Chandler.
SP.P: I warmed the bed for Mrs. Harvey and Miss Woodcock.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you warm the bed on Tuesday night!

SP.SPEAKER: Chandler.
SP.P: I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Who were there?

SP.SPEAKER: Chandler.
SP.P: Doctor Griffinburg, his wife, Mrs. Harvey, and Miss Woodcock.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you observe any thing?

SP.SPEAKER: Chandler.
SP.P: They were all very merry.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did they laugh as if it was something sudden?

SP.SPEAKER: Chandler.
SP.P: I can't say what they were so merry about.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
SP.P: Did you ever see Mrs. Harvey there before?

SP.SPEAKER: Chandler.
SP.P: No, never.

DIV1.P: I am his Lordship's cook at Woodcote: I was confined to my bed on account of an accident I had; I was visited on Wednesday the 23d of December.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you know by whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Greenoch.
SP.P: One Miss Woodcock came in with Doctor Griffinburg.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: In what manner did she appear?

SP.SPEAKER: Greenoch.
SP.P: Very chearful.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did the appear in any distress of mind?

SP.SPEAKER: Greenoch.
SP.P: No; she said mine was a very great misfor∣tune; then she said to Dr. Griffinburg, Sir, will you take a walk; the Doctor said he would; she went out and put her hat on, and came into my room; then the Doc∣tor and she went out to take a walk.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I am a merchant: I have been acquainted with Lord Baltimore; I have known him about eight years; I was one of the party that made Lord Baltimore a visit at Woodcote.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Who were the party?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: There was Captain Pezer; a gentleman; and there was a young lady with us.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Under whose protection was she?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Under mine. We came there about five o'clock.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: What day was it?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I believe on Wednesday the 23d of December: when we went up stairs I found my Lord, Mrs. Griffin∣burg, and Dr. Griffinburg, Mrs. Harvey, and Miss Wood∣cock, all at tea.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did not some amusement go forward in the evening?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Yes, my Lord proposed to make a shade.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did Miss Woodcock lend a hand to this!

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Yes; first she pinned them, and afterwards took needle and thread and joined them.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: While these shades went on, where was she? after she had done her work, what became of Miss Woodcock?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: I saw them standing there all together; I went behind to perform, because we did not perform at a time; I was a performer, and Mr. Pezer, and a little black boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you see any more there?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P:
While this exhibition was going forward, and almost over, my Lord and I came from behind the cur∣tain; my Lord went on, and I stopt at the chimney at the corner: I believe he went up to the ladies; I saw my Lord in a moment afterwards, sitting in an elbow∣chair; Miss Woodcock came after him; my Lord sat down in the elbow-chair, and Miss Woodcock sat down upon his knee, with her arm upon his neck, not quite round his neck, rather upon his shoulder: I then ob∣served my Lord kissed her, and he drew back, and she kissed him, I saw it plain: after this we went to supper, and I saw Miss Woodcock sit next to Miss Forrest, and she was sitting next my Lord, and she seemed to be very chearful and in good spirits; I observed one thing more, she poured out a glass of wine for Miss Forrest, and one for herself, and they drank to my Lord and the compa∣ny;
after supper was over, they wished us a good night. Next morning the ladies were not below when I came down; my Lord was already below, and Mr. Pezer; then the ladies came in successively, and they sat down to breakfast; I went to take a walk with my Lord; after∣wards I came back and found the ladies sitting in the room; I saw particularly Miss Woodcock and Miss For∣rest running upon the terras, seemingly in high spirits and chearful; the other ladies walked behind.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: During the time you was there, was the lady under any constraint, uneasiness, or concern?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Not in the least.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Could you observe she laboured under any private uneasiness and grief?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: No, not to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
SP.P: Pray, Sir, where do you live in London?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: In Newman-street.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: You are guardian to Miss Forrest?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: No, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: I thought you said she was under your pro∣tection.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: She is my housekeeper.
I was one of the three people that went to visit Lord Baltimore; I went down with the last witness.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Who went down in your party?

SP.SPEAKER: Pezer.
SP.P: Mr. Smith, and Miss Forrest.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: What day did you go down?

SP.SPEAKER: Pezer.
SP.P: On Wednesday the 23d of December.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: When you came there, how was my Lord engaged?

SP.SPEAKER: Pezer.
SP.P: He was in the room with Mrs. Harvey and Miss Woodcock; they were drinking tea.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: How did you amuse yourselves in the evening?

SP.SPEAKER: Pezer.
SP.P: My Lord darkened part of the room; on the the other side was placed a candle; I myself and others played there.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you remember who assisted in join∣ing the cloths together?

SP.SPEAKER: Pezer.
SP.P: The dies did, Miss Woodcock and the others; the cords broke and it sell down.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did that create any laughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Pezer.
SP.P: May be it did; I did not observe these things.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you remember who supped there!

SP.SPEAKER: Pezer.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Miss Woodcock was one of the party; was she not?

SP.SPEAKER: Pezer.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did she refrain from drinking?

SP.SPEAKER: Pezer.
SP.P: No, she eat and drank as all the rest did; I took a bottle and said, You have no wine, ladies: and I poured them out wine; there was a hare froze in the ice, and they ran down to see it, and they ran up again; Miss Woodcock was one of them, upon honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you observe any appearance of gloom in her countenance?

SP.SPEAKER: Pezer.
SP.P: No, not the least, or discontent; she appeared as the rest of the company.
I am housekeeper to Mr. Smith; I was at Lord Balti∣more's with these two gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: What time was that?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: It was the 23d.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Of what month?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: I can't tell.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was it before Christmas?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you see me there, and Miss Woodcock?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: What time did you go there?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: About five in the evening. I saw there my Lord, Mrs. Harvey, Miss Woodcock, Dr. Griffinburg, and Mrs. Griffinburg.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: What were they doing together?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: Drinking tea.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was Miss Woodcock drinking tea with them?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: Yes: I joined company.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was you left alone with Miss Wood∣cock any time!

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you remember any pictures?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you remember my taking a walk?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: No; I do not remember it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you remember any thing about the pictures?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: She (Miss Woodcock) got a candle, and look∣ed at the pictures, and shewed them me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did she then appear dejected?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: No; she was as merry as the merriest.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you remember the magic lanthorn?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: Yes; there was something of that sort; I don't know what you call it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did she join in the company that night?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: Yes; she was as much diverted as the merriest; she laughed; I lent her my pincushion; she helped to pin them; and when the needles and thread came up, she helped to sew, she was as much pleased as any of the rest; she appeared to me to have the same liberty as the rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Who supped with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: We all supped together.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did Miss Woodcock eat any supper?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: Yes; she eat the same, and as hearty as the rest; the laughed, and was as merry as the rest. As soon as supper was over, the women all got up together, and bid his Lordship a good night. As the four women retired after supper, we were going through a gallery, I said, there are a great many doors. She said, Yes; and if I would go with her, she would shew me my Lord's bed-room. I went in with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Had you any conversation upon that occasion? Did any thing more pass that night?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: No nothing at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: What passed next morning?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: Us women joined together to breakfast: the gentlemen had breakfasted before, except Dr. Griffin∣burg; he sat down to breakfast with us; Miss Wood∣cock breakfasted with us.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: That was on Thursay morning, I believe?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: Yes it was.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did she eat any breakfast?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P:
Yes, as much as the rest. After breakfast we walked up the terras; we talked with Miss Woodcock; at breakfast she said she was ashamed of her linen; that if she had thought of his Lordship's staying so long down there, she would have provided herself with li∣nen.
When we were walking upon the terras, she told me, she had never been there before, but had lived in my Lord's family above a twelvemonth.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you walk out that morning?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: It was a very cold morning, and she and I ran several times on the terras by way of diversion. As soon as I came in again, I lent her a shift, an apron, and a pair of ruffles. I went into my own room, (the room I lay in.)

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Had you any conversation with Miss Woodcock at that time?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: She was not in my room at that time.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: What did she tell you there?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: I don't remember. After I had brought up the linen into her room, she told me not to make myself uneasy; for as soon as she got home to his Lordship's house, she would send the linen by one of the servants.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: So she looked upon my house as her own home?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did she eat and drink there at that time?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: Yes, she did, and poured herself out a glass of wine, and poured out some for me too.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did she drink to any body?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: Yes; she drank Lord Baltimore's health.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did she appear to be in a dejected state, or did she appear to be a woman that was well contented with her situation? Did she appear to be a person that was at liberty, or under restraint or confine∣ment?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: She appeared to be at liberty as much as any body else; she might have got away if she would; she was in as high spirits as any of the rest; always in high spirits.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: You say she was just as chearful as any of the rest, neither more nor less, but exactly as chearful that you observed?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: And eat and drank just as the rest did exactly?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest:
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Did you make that observation at that time?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: No, not a particular observation.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: When did you first make the observation?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: When we were at supper.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: That was that time?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: No; this is the next day.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: How came you to think of it?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: I don't know.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: Upon what occasion did she tell you she had been there a twelvemouth?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: As we were coming off from the terras, I asked her if she had ever been down there before; she said No; but she had lived in his Lordship's family above a twelve∣month.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: How long have you lived with Mr. Smith, and in what capacity?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: I have been his housekeeper this twelvemonth.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Where did you come from to him?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: From Nottinghamshire.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Who did you live with there?

SP.SPEAKER: Forrest.
SP.P: I came from my father.
I work for Lord Baltimore at Woodcote, as a carpen∣ter.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you remember my coming down in my carriage there?

SP.SPEAKER: Walter.
SP.P: Yes, I do. His Lordship came with three la∣dies and a gentleman; I knew Mrs. Griffinburg; there were two young ones, whose names I did not know; I have since heard who they were.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: What are their names?

SP.SPEAKER: Walter.
SP.P: Mrs. Harvey and Sarah Woodcock. I saw one lady get out, and my Lord followed her: she appeared very agreeable and loving: I saw her again on Tuesday walking in the park; Mrs. Griffinburg was with her; she appeared very gay: she was arm in arm with Mrs. Griffinburg; I saw her walking about at other times while there; she always appeared gay and chearful; she seemed to be at liberty to go where she pleased.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Baker.
SP.P: Was not somebody always with her?

SP.SPEAKER: Walter.
SP.P: Yes, I believe there was.
I am governess to my Lord's daughters; one of them is since dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Pray, Madam, when did you first see this lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Dunning.
SP.P: On Christmas-day she was introduced with her hat, cloak, and gloves on.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: As what?

SP.SPEAKER: Dunning.
SP.P: A companion to the misses.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was she introduced by my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Dunning.
SP.P: He said it was a person very well rocommend∣ed by her father to be a companion to the misses.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: What said she to this?

SP.SPEAKER: Dunning.
SP.P: She made no reply.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: In what way did she live in the fami∣ly while she staid there?

SP.SPEAKER: Dunning.
SP.P: She eat and drank with me and the ladies, my Lord's daughters, as chearful as any body; she break∣fasted, dined, and supped with Madam Saunier and the family.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: What was she employed in?

SP.SPEAKER: Dunning.
SP.P: Sometimes working: on Saturday evening she was at work, and several parts of the day.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Had my Lord and she any conversa∣tion?

SP.SPEAKER: Dunning.
SP.P: They had upon Christmas evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: What was their subject?

SP.SPEAKER: Dunning.
SP.P: Many subjects; they were talking of scrip∣ture.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: What were they talking of?

SP.SPEAKER: Dunning.
SP.P: They were talking of Paul, and Saul, and Isaiah, and Adam and Eve.—Miss Woodcock said Adam was created upright; at which we all laughed.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Pray did she join in that laugh?

SP.SPEAKER: Dunning.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Pray do you remember Mrs. Pynson's coming to see the ladies?

SP.SPEAKER: Dunning.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: She dined and supped with you I think?

SP.SPEAKER: Dunning.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: How was she employed that day?

SP.SPEAKER: Dunning.
SP.P: That was on Saturday; she was making gauze ruffles and aprons.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was any thing said about her playing at cards that evening?

SP.SPEAKER: Dunning.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You had opportunities of couversing with her, and sometimes, I suppose, alone?

SP.SPEAKER: Dunning.
SP.P: I was with her many times alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Could you discover, from the stile of her conversation, that she was uneasy, and detained a∣gainst her will, or any secret discontent?

SP.SPEAKER: Dunning.
SP.P: No, not in the least; nor did I know to the contrary, nor who she was, till the was gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: From the manner of her being intro∣duted to you, with her hat and cloak on, she certainly assisted me to impose upon you, or she could certainly have contradicted it?

SP.SPEAKER: Dunning.
SP.P: Yes, I suppose so.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Did she not come from Woodcote that day?

SP.SPEAKER: Dunning.
SP.P: I did not know she had been at Woodcote; I never heard a word of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Your apartments were distinct from the rest of the family, were they not?

SP.SPEAKER: Dunning.
SP.P: There is a room where the masters attend upon the ladies: there is a room for writing, and ano∣ther for musick, and the ladies are employed every hour of the day with one or other of the masters.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: It is a very large house, is it not?

SP.SPEAKER: Dunning.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you know of her being in con∣finement?

SP.SPEAKER: Dunning.
SP.P: Not in the least.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Would she play at cards?

SP.SPEAKER: Dunning.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
SP.P: So you never knew all this time that this girl was in the house; you who are governess to his daughters and lived in the same house?

SP.SPEAKER: Dunning.
SP.P: No, I did not know she was in the house till they came back again.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
SP.P: Or did you ever know Mrs. Harvey was there?

SP.SPEAKER: Dunning.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
SP.P: Did the young ladies never eat with my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Dunning.
SP.P: When he has no company sometimes they do.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
SP.P: Did you ever see Mrs. Harvey before?

SP.SPEAKER: Dunning.
SP.P:
No, I never knew there was such a woman
in the house till this broke out; I never saw Harvey or Woodcock till Christmas-day.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Pray, did you know Miss Woodcock?

SP.SPEAKER: Saunier.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you remember her being at Wood∣cote that December?

SP.SPEAKER: Saunier.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was she introduced to you at any time, and in what character?

SP.SPEAKER: Saunier.
SP.P: Yes, on Christ mas-day, as a companion to the young ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: How long was she at the house in town?

SP.SPEAKER: Saunier.
SP.P: Three days, to my knowledge.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Could she have gone out of my house if she thought proper? Were any orders given to the family to keep her in?

SP.SPEAKER: Saunier.
SP.P: No, she was under no restraint; she could have got out whenever she pleased.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you ever see her in tears?

SP.SPEAKER: Saunier.
SP.P: No, she was as chearful as we.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you know of her being to have a bed in your room?

SP.SPEAKER: Saunier.
SP.P: Yes, there was a bed made up there.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did she ever lie in it?

SP.SPEAKER: Saunier.
SP.P: No, she would not lie in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: What sort of a room was it?

SP.SPEAKER: Saunier.
SP.P: It was a little room; there were two beds in it; it was a good room; there was a bed made on pur∣pose for her to lie in my room.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Had she a nightcap in your room?

SP.SPEAKER: Saunier.
SP.P: Yes, and she went and fetched it out.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you hear any thing said of Miss Woodcock's application to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Saunier.
SP.P: She refused to lie in that room, and said she would speak with me first: I told her I should see her a∣gain; she fetched the night-cap out, and said she did not choose to lie with any body in the room.

DIV1.P:
Lord Baltimore sent a note with his compliments to me on the 26th of December, and that if I was not en∣gaged,
he would send his coach for me. I went; I saw my Lord, his two daughters, Miss Woodcock Mrs. Sau∣nier, Mrs. Dunning, and Dr. Griffinburg; we all din∣ed together.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: How did Miss. Woodcock appear at dinner?

SP.SPEAKER: Pynsons.
SP.P: Extremely chearful, and the most pleased of any person there.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did she dine, and eat as other people did?—Did you stay there after dinner?

SP.SPEAKER: Pynsons.
SP.P: I drank tea there and supped.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: How did you spend your afternoon?

SP.SPEAKER: Pynsons.
SP.P: The young lady after dinner, and Miss Juli∣et, got up, that is she that is dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: I believe she was about fifteen at that time.

SP.SPEAKER: Pynsons.
SP.P: Yes.—They got up, and went into the draw∣ing-room together, both laughing, immoderately. She was chearful and gay till tea-time came on, and then they were all at work. My Lord said, My ladies don't love cards: I said to my Lord, the ladies are very chear∣ful at work, (she was at work on gauze); she said it would wash well, and th t the apron I had on would wash well; it had been washed. I asked Mrs. Saunier how long that lady had been in the family; she said the day before. I observed she was extremely chearful, and appeared as if she had been in the family a twelvemonth. She and Miss Juliet seemed very fond of each other.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you observe any discontent of mind?

SP.SPEAKER: Pynsons.
SP.P: She appeared to me to be at her full liberty as much as I; she appeared under no restraint.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: She did not appear to be a person with an afflicted mind, did she? Did you see her cry?

SP.SPEAKER: Pynsons.
SP.P: No: if laughing is crying, she had suffici∣ent of that.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
SP.P: Are you a married woman?

SP.SPEAKER: Pynsons.
SP.P: No, I am not: I have been married.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
SP.P: Where do you live?

SP.SPEAKER: Pynsons.
SP.P: In Warwick Court Holborn.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
SP.P: Are you of any employment, or bu∣finess?

SP.SPEAKER: Pynsons.
SP.P: No, I live upon my fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
SP.P: You went to my Lord Baltimore's, and there were these people, my Lord and his two daugh∣ters, Mrs. Saunier, Mrs. Dunning, Dr. Griffinburg, and Miss Woodcock: it struck you very much, I think, that this girl was so very merry?

SP.SPEAKER: Pynsons.
SP.P: As I had not been in the family for five months, I enquired after her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr, Serj. Leigh.
SP.P: So then she was so extremely chearful, that you enquired after her on that account?

SP.SPEAKER: Pynsons.
SP.P: I was going to say to the ladies, tell me what you laugh at, that I may laugh with you, but my Lord was there, and so I thought I would not.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
SP.P: How long did you stay after dinner?

SP.SPEAKER: Pynsons.
SP.P: I supped there,

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
SP.P: Did the young ladies and my Lord Baltimore sup with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Pynsons.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
SP.P: And were they all as chearful at night?

SP.SPEAKER: Pynsons.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
SP.P: But this girl struck you?

SP.SPEAKER: Pynsons.
SP.P: They were all chearful.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
SP.P: You knew Mrs. Dunning was an in∣structor to the young ladies, and Mrs. Saunier: and yet you had not the curiosity to enquire who this young lady was?

SP.SPEAKER: Pynsons.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
SP.P: Well then, you thought, I suppose, she was brought in merely to laugh. As you took so much notice of this girl, I wonder your curiosity did not lead you to enquire in what capacity she was in the family?

SP.SPEAKER: Pynsons.
SP.P: No; my Lord was present; it was when Mrs. Saunier went to the fire I spoke to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
SP.P: Well, but suppose my Lord was there, you was on a good footing; there was no great distance kept.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: If I understand you right, the reason why you took notice of this young woman was, because you had never seen her there before?

SP.SPEAKER: Pynsons.
SP.P: Yes.

DIV1.P: I am a mantua-maker; I was sent for to my Lord Bal∣timore's the 26th of December.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: For what purpose?

SP.SPEAKER: Okeley.
SP.P: To make a gown for a young lady, whom, I since understand, is Miss Woodcock: I made the gown.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you receive any directions from Miss Woodcock about making the gown?

SP.SPEAKER: Okeley.
SP.P: I did. I asked her if she chose it with an a∣pron, or without? She said, without an apron.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did she choose what colour her gown should be?

SP.SPEAKER: Okeley.
SP.P: I asked her what I was to measure her for? Mrs. Griffinburg asked, Would she have a night-gown, or a negligee? She chose a night-gown, because I told her it was impossible to have a negligee made by next day; Mrs. Griffinburg had said at first, you must have it made by to-morrow: and then she chose a night-gown. I ask∣ed her how she chose to have it made; whether to but∣ton before, or with a loose stomacher? She said with a loose stomacher.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was it made?

SP.SPEAKER: Okeley.
SP.P: It was.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: When did you bring it home?

SP.SPEAKER: Okeley.
SP.P: I came to try it on at 9 o'clock the same evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore
SP.P: Where did you find Miss Woodcock?

SP.SPEAKER: Okeley.
SP.P: At the top of the stairs, with a candle in her hand. I went into her bed-room; I tried it on; she de∣fired me then to be as quick as I could, because it was supper-time.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you go away as soon as you had done?

SP.SPEAKER: Okeley.
SP.P: Yes; and came again the next day, and brought it home: I saw her then.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Had you any conversation with her then?

SP.SPEAKER: Okeley.
SP.P: No; none.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you bring the stomacher?

SP.SPEAKER: Okeley.
SP.P: I asked her to excuse me till Monday; she said by all means, only let me have the gown by dressing∣time to-morrow. And being in so great a hurry, going to supper, she did not let me take the pins out; I told her I hoped she would excuse any little flaw that might hap∣pen. She said she would, by all means.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you see her on Sunday.

SP.SPEAKER: Okeley.
SP.P: did. There was Mrs. Dunning, the two la∣dies, Doctor Griffinburg, and another lady there. She appeared very brisk and merry; she was coming to the fire to Dr. Griffinburg, and there stood talking.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Had she an opportunity to get out if she would?

SP.SPEAKER: Okeley.
SP.P: Yes, she had; she was under no restraint, and was alone on the top of the stairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did her eyes appear swelled with crying?

SP.SPEAKER: Okeley.
SP.P: Not in the least.

DIV1.P: I am a milliner, and live in Holborn; I was sent for to Lord Baltimore's; I saw a young lady; I did not know who she was.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: What did she bespeak?

SP.SPEAKER: Hadley.
SP.P: She chose a cap and a cloak, and some petti∣coats, and ordered some muslin to be brought.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did she shew any attention to the fa∣shion and make of the goods?

SP.SPEAKER: Hadley.
SP.P: I shewed her some; she did not chuse them. She did not say any thing particular, only objected to a cloak that it was too dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: The question is, Did she want them sashionable?—There were under petticoats?

SP.SPEAKER: Hadley.
SP.P: Yes; slannel petticoats.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did she give any directions how these were to be made?

SP.SPEAKER: Hadley.
SP.P: She desired these might be made to tye before, and they must be brought home by two o'clock. I never had such an order before.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did this young woman appear easy and chearful?

SP.SPEAKER: Hadley.
SP.P: She did not seem distressed.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Cox.
SP.P: You never saw any tears, or any thing of that sort?

SP.SPEAKER: Hadley.
SP.P: No; none at all.

DIV1.P: I am a musician.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you teach any body music at my house?

SP.SPEAKER: Humell.
SP.P: I taught Lord Baltimore's two daughters e∣very day.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P:
Do you remember going to my house
in December? You know the time I refer to; you came to see some company in the parlour.

SP.SPEAKER: Humell.
SP.P: No; they were up stairs: it was the 28th of December.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: What time of the day?

SP.SPEAKER: Humell.
SP.P: Between eleven and twelve.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: When you came there, where was I?

SP.SPEAKER: Humell.
SP.P: I did not see Lord Baltimore at first when I came in; first I met Mrs. Saunier and a strange woman I did not know.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Who did she turn out to be afterwards?

SP.SPEAKER: Humell.
SP.P: After that I went to the room to my scholars, and there was the eldest daughter and my Lord; they desired me to go and fetch a music-book from below; when I came up stairs into the room, I found his Lord∣ship and the young woman, Miss Woodcock.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Have you seen her since?

SP.SPEAKER: Humell.
SP.P: That was the only time I saw her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: When you came back again, you saw somebody in the parlour; did you not?

SP.SPEAKER: Humell.
SP.P: I saw his Lordship and Miss Woodcock playing together. She had her back to the fire side, and she was handling her work. My Lord took her work from her, and pulled it from her; and she pulled it from him.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: What was the work?

SP.SPEAKER: Humell.
SP.P: A handkerchief, or some such thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: She was not crying, or weeping then?

SP.SPEAKER: Humell.
SP.P: No; she was gay and free.

DIV1.P: I am butler to my Lord at his house in Southampton∣row. I remember Miss Woodcock's going out, on Mon∣day the 28th of December, with Mrs. Griffinburg and Miss Fanny. She is eight years old. They went in a hackney-coach. I handed them all in.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did she go there freely?

SP.SPEAKER: Burn.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Under no constraint?

SP.SPEAKER: Burn.
SP.P: no; not in the least.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did you see them all go freely into the coach? They were to drive to Queen-street, Soho?

SP.SPEAKER: Burn.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: You being the butler, very frequent∣ly attend the hall, and go to the door, do you not?

SP.SPEAKER: Burn.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Is the door ever locked in the day time?

SP.SPEAKER: Burn.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Are you pretty much in the hall?

SP.SPEAKER: Burn.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was any order given to stop her if she should want to go out?

SP.SPEAKER: Burn.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Should you have stopped her, if she had offered to go out?

SP.SPEAKER: Burn.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Baker.
SP.P: The time you speak of was Monday the 28th; when did you first see Miss Woodcock?

SP.SPEAKER: Burn.
SP.P: I believe the day they went down to Woodcote: that was the first time I had ever seen her.

DIV1.P: I am servant to Dr. Griffinburg.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you remember any body coming in a coach to Dr. Griffinburg's on the 28th December?

SP.SPEAKER: Jacobs.
SP.P: Yes; Mrs. Griffinburg, Miss Fanny, and Miss Woodcock. When they came, I opened the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Who came out first?

SP.SPEAKER: Jacobs.
SP.P: Mrs. Griffinburg.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Where did the coach stop?

SP.SPEAKER: Jacobs.
SP.P: About five or six doors off. Mrs. Griffinburg took Miss Fanny out, and brought her into the passage, and Miss Woodcock followed.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Where did they go?

SP.SPEAKER: Jacobs.
SP.P: Into the parlour. Mrs. Griffinburg came down twice or three times into the kitchen.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: How long was she out of the parlour at a time?

SP.SPEAKER: Jacobs.
SP.P: About eight or ten minutes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Then nobody was left with Miss Woodcock but Miss Fanny. Was the street door so fastened that she could not open it?

SP.SPEAKER: Jacobs.
SP.P: No? it was not fastened at all: she could have gone to the door in a minute.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you remember the parlour fire being out?

SP.SPEAKER: Jacobs.
SP.P:
I made it up. Miss Woodcock said she was cold. Mrs. Griffinburg took her cloak, and put it on
her. She said, Madam, you'll spoil me. She seemed merry.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Not at all dejected?

SP.SPEAKER: Jacobs.
SP.P: No.

DIV1.P: I am fourteen years old.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: When was you fourteen?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: A quarter of a year ago.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Don't you live with Dr. Griffinburg?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you remember any thing of any company coming to your master's house in December?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Who were they?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Miss Woodcock, Mrs. Griffinburgh, and Miss Fanny.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: How did they come?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: They came in a coach.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you know where they stopt?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: They stopt at a milk-cellar.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: How far is that from your street-door?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: About five yards.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Then they were obliged to walk five yards to your door. Could the coach have come nearer up to the door?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: What room did they go into?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: The back parlour.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Is that on the ground floor?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: How far is it from the door of that parlour to your street door?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: About three yards.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: When Mrs. Griffinburg was come home, there was some dinner preparing, was there not?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: There was.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did she stay in the room all the time?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: No; she went down stairs: the first time, she staid a quarter of an hour, I believe, and went again after that.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Could she have gone to the door, and let herself out, if she pleased?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Yes, she could.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was nobody with her besides the little girl?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: No; there was not.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: When did they come?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: At four o'clock.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: That was day-light, was it not?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Yes.

DIV1.P: I am a servant of Lord Baltimore's. I went to Dr. Griffinburg.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did not you go from thence to White∣chapel?

SP.SPEAKER: Vanburg.
SP.P: Yes; I went with Lord Baltimore, Dr. Grif∣finburg, Sarah Woodcock, Miss Fanny, and Mr. Morris.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Pray what time did you get to the tavern?

SP.SPEAKER: Vanburgh.
SP.P: It might be between eight and nine.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: How long might you stay there?

SP.SPEAKER: Vanburg.
SP.P: It might be two hours. Miss Woodcock, Miss Fanny, and I, were left by ourselves in that tavern in Whitechapel.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Where were the others gone to?

SP.SPEAKER: Vanburg.
SP.P: I don't know; they went out of the room.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Had Miss Woodcock any opportunity to get out of that room, if she pleased? If she had offer∣ed to go out of the room, should you have stopped her?

SP.SPEAKER: Vanburg.
SP.P: No; I had no such orders; and if I had, I should not have pretended to have stopped her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Where did Miss Woodcock lie that night?

SP.SPEAKER: Vanburg.
SP.P: I saw her in my Lord's bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Pray how did she go to bed?

SP.SPEAKER: Vanburg.
SP.P: She went up stairs; she sat some time in the room before she went to bed; she was as chearful as any person could be, and was very merry.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was the under any restraint?

SP.SPEAKER: Vanburg.
SP.P: No; she was under no restraint whatever.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Had she her liberty?

SP.SPEAKER: Vanburg.
SP.P: She had her full liberty.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Do you remember her going to my Lord Mansfield's? Do you know what became of the key of the door where she lodged?

SP.SPEAKER: Vanburg.
SP.P: She put it in her pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: Morris.
SP.P: I am a linen-draper.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Have you any connection with these people? How came you one of the party at the Crown and Magpye?

SP.SPEAKER: Morris,
SP.P: Dr. Griffinburg had paid me some money that day, and he desired me to carry a letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: For what reason?

SP.SPEAKER: Morris.
SP.P: Because he could not speak English very well.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Did he direct you where to go?

SP.SPEAKER: Morris.
SP.P: No; he went with me in the coach. We went to the Crown and Magpye, Whitechapal. I asked Dr. Griffinburg what was the matter? He said nothing at all. I followed him into the room.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Where was the room?

SP.SPEAKER: Morris.
SP.P: On the ground floor. I passed by the bar; there was a woman selling of oysters on one hand, and two or three people in the bar, and several in the kitch∣en, all of which we passed; and I saw in one room a dozen people.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: What passed when you got into the room?

SP.SPEAKER: Morris.
SP.P: Miss Woodcock asked who had got the letter? I said, I have. She took the letter out of my pocket, and said, this is my own hand writing; go and tell my father or sister to come here directly. I went. Mrs. Berry said, they were not at home, and could not tell when they would come home. I went back to my Lord again. He was for sending me to Justice Fielding to enquire for Mr. Woodcock. Miss Woodcock thought Justice Fielding would do no business at that time of night, and her father would probably be at home soon. We staid about half an hour. She proposed sending the letter, and leaving it there. My Lord asked her if she thought Mrs. Berry would deliver the letter? She said she would. She proposed writing a sew more lines. She opened the letter, and wrote. My Lord desired to see what she wrote. She read it to him. There were a∣bout five or six lines. I went and gave the letter to Mrs. Berry. Mr. Woodcock was not yet come home.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: If this young woman had wanted to have gone herself to her father could any body have hindered her?

SP.SPEAKER: Morris.
SP.P:
She stood between me and the door. There was nothing could hinder her from going out, if she
chose to lift up the latch of the door. We went back, and I was set down at Bridges-street to go to Sir John Fielding's. My Lord desired me to ask for Miss Wood∣cock's father and sister, and desire them to come to her at Dr. Griffinburg's house. When I went there, I could not find her father. I was carried directly to Sir John. He asked me, how I came to go with them? I told him Dr. Griffinburg asked me to go with a let∣ter. He called one of his clerks to write a card to Miss Woodcock, to desire her to come to him to meet her fa∣ther and friends there. I went with Mr. Lee, one of Sir John Fielding's clerks, to Dr. Griffinburg's. He deli∣vered the card to Miss Woodcock. I was rather fright∣ned by Sir John. He told me it was a dangerous affair, and advised me to have nothing more to do with it. I said I would not.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Was the card desiring her to come that night, or some other time, to meet her father?

SP.SPEAKER: Morris.
SP.P: That night.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Was not her father then at Sir John's that night?

SP.SPEAKER: Morris.
SP.P: I don't know.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: Was not you sent to enquire whether the father was not at Sir John Fielding's?

SP.SPEAKER: Morris.
SP.P: They never satisfied me?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: What was the answer she made on de∣livering the card? What did she say with regard to Sir John?

SP.SPEAKER: Morris.
SP.P: The last words she said was, But desire them to come to Dr. Griffinburg's.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Baltimore.
SP.P: When she was at the tavern writing that letter, did I give any direction to her?

SP.SPEAKER: Morris.
SP.P: I did not hear my Lord say a single word. It was all wrote by her own hand, and of her own dictating.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
SP.P: Was my Lord Baltimore in the room?

SP.SPEAKER: Morris.
SP.P: Yes.

THE prisoner at the bar, Lord Baltimore, stands in∣dicted for feloniously ravishing and carnally know∣ing Sarah Woodcock, spinster, against her will, on the 22d of December last at Epsom; against the statute which makes this offence felony: and the other two prisoners are indicted as accessaries before the fact, by feloniously and maliciously procuring, aiding and abetting Lord Baltimore, to commit the said rape, at the said time and place. To this they have pleaded Not Guilty; and you are to try if they are guilty. Before I state to you the evidence, I will mention to you two or three things: In the first place, my Lord complains of libels, and print∣ed accounts of this transaction, which have been circu∣lated. It is a most unjustifiable practice, and tends to the perversion of public justice; and therefore if you have seen any thing printed on the side of the prosecu∣tix or the prisoners, I must desire you to divest your∣selves of any prejudice that such publications may have occasioned, and give your verdict only on the evidence now laid before you. Another thing I desire, is, that whichever way the verdict is given, none of the friends of any of the parties will make use of any expression of approbation o applause, which are extremely improper and indecent in a court of justice, and I shall certainly commit any person whom I shall know to be guilty of it. The last thing I shall mention to you, is, to desire that no resentment you may feel at the manner in which she was carried to Lord Baltimore's house, may have any in∣fluence on your verdict; for however unwarrantable the manner was, in which she came into his power, if at the time he lay with her it was by her consent, he is not guilty of the offence of which he is indicted; though it was proper to be given in evidence in this trial, to ac∣count for her being with him, and his having an oppor∣tunity of committing the crime; and to shew, from the indirect manner of getting her to his house, the greater probability that her account is true. Having said this, I will now state to you the whole evidence as particular∣ly as I can.

P.HI: Mr. Baron Smythe then stated the whole of the evidence to the jury, as before given, which took up three hours, and on account of the length of it is not repeated here; and then con∣cluded,

SP.P: In point of law, the fact is fully proved on my Lord and the other two prisoners, if you believe the evidence of Sarah Woodcock. It is a crime which in its nature can only be proved by the woman on whom it is commit∣ted; for she only can tell whether she consented or no; it is, as my Lord observes, very easy to be made, and hard to be disproved; and the desence can only be col∣lected from circumstances; from these you must judge whether her evidence is or is not to be believed. Lord Hale, in his history of the pleas of the crown Vol. I. p. 632, , lays down two rules: I. If complaint is not made soon after the injury is supposed to be received; 2. If it is not follow∣ed by a recent prosecution; a strong presumption arises that the complaint is malicious. She has owned the in∣jury was received December 21st, and the complaint was not made till December 29th; but she has accounted for it in the manner you have heard. The strong part of the case, on behalf of the prisoners, is, her not complain∣ing when she was at Lord Mansfield's, the supreme ma∣gistrate in the kingdom in criminal matters: you have heard how she has explained and accounted for her con∣duct in that particular, which you will judge of. Upon the whole, if you believe that she made the discovery as soon as she knew she had an opportunity of doing it, and that her account is true, you will find all the prisoners guilty; if you believe that the did not make the discovery as soon as she had an opportunity, and from thence, or other circumstances, are not satisfied her account is true, you will find them all not guilty; for if he is not guilty, they cannot be so; for they cannot be accessary to a crime which was never committed.

P.HI: After Baron Smythe's summing up of the evidence, the jury went out for about an hour and twenty minutes, and then re∣turned to the court.

SP.SPEAKER: Clerk of Arr.
SP.P: Gentlemen, are you all agreed on your verdict?

SP.SPEAKER: Jury.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Clerk of Arr.
SP.P: Who shall say for you?

SP.SPEAKER: Jury.
SP.P: Our Foreman.

SP.SPEAKER: Clerk of Arr.
SP.P: Frederick Calvert, Esq Baron of Balti∣more, hold up your hand. (which he did) Gentlemen of the Jury, look upon the prisoners: How say you, is Fre∣derick Calvert, Esq Baron of Baltimore, guilty of this felony and rape whereof he stands indicted, or not guilty?

SP.SPEAKER: Jury.
SP.P: Not guilty.

SP.SPEAKER: Clerk of Arr.
SP.P: How say you, Gentlemen, is Elizabeth Griffinburgh guilty of this felony and rape whereof she stands indicted, or not guilty?

SP.SPEAKER: Jury.
SP.P: Not guilty.

SP.SPEAKER: Clerk of Arr.
SP.P: How say you, Gentlemen, is Ann Harvey, otherwise Darby, guilty of this felony and rape where∣of she stands indicted, or not guilty?

SP.SPEAKER: Jury.
SP.P: Not guilty.

SP.SPEAKER: Clerk of Arr.
SP.P: Harken to your verdict, as the court hath recorded it. You say that Frederick Calvert, Esq Ba∣ron of Baltimore, in the kingdom of Ireland, is not guil∣ty, and so you say all.
And you say that Elizabeth Griffinburg and Ann Har∣vey are not guilty, and so you say all.
